questions.text: Which of the following drains the cavernous sinus into the transverse sinus?
questions.solution:
The Superior petrosal sinuses lie in the anterior part of the attached margin of the tentorium cerebelli along the upper border of the petrous temporal bone. It drains the cavernous sinus into the transverse sinus.

The inferior petrosal sinuses, right and left, lie in the corresponding petro-occipital fissure, and drain the cavernous sinus into the superior bulb of the internal jugular vein.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume- 3, 8th Edition, Page No - 221

choices.text: Removing all of the sinus mucosa

questions.text: The goals of endoscopic sinus surgery include all of the following except -
questions.solution:
In functional endoscopic sinus surgery, it is critical to preserve as much normal mucosa as technically feasible. Removal of mucosa prolongs the healing process and leads to scarring with abnormal, poorly functioning mucosa. The other choices represent key principles of functional endoscopic sinus surgery.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition, page no 774

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with long-standing hypertension and poorly controlled diabetes. He presents complaining of several months of breathlessness with exertion, acute episodes of shortness of breath when recumbent, and lower extremity edema. On examination, he has an elevated JVP and an S4 on auscultation. Echocardiography shows a LVEF 55% with a large left atrium. You suspect this patient has heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). Drugs targeting which of the following has convincingly demonstrated mortality reduction for patients with HFpEF?
questions.solution:
Although therapeutic targets in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction are relatively abundant and guided by the targets of disease modification, trials in heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) have been largely disappointing.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (option A) have been studied in many mechanistic studies and shown no convincing mortality benefit in HFpEF.

Similarly, angiotensin receptor blockers (option B) were studied in the CHARM-Preserved and I-PRESERVE studies and found no mortality benefit.

Sildenafil (a PDE-5 inhibitor) was shown to improve filling pressures and right ventricular function in patients with HFpEF, but it did not show mortality benefit.

Finally, digoxin, which inhibits sodium potassium-ATPase, was shown to have no role in treating HFpEF in the DIG study.

Overall, symptom management and blood pressure control are the goals in HFpEF treatment now. One should also remain vigilant for myocardial ischemia.

Reference: Harrison's principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1941

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a field block?
questions.solution:
A field block is a local anesthetic injection that targets terminal cutaneous nerves. Field blocks are used commonly by surgeons to minimize incisional pain and may be used as a supplementary technique or as a sole anesthetic for minor, superficial procedures. Anesthesiologists often use field blocks to anesthetize the superficial cervical plexus for procedures involving the neck or shoulder; the intercostobrachial nerve for surgery involving the medial upper extremity proximal to the elbow (in combination with a brachial plexus nerve block); and the saphenous nerve for surgery involving the medial leg or ankle joint (in combination with a sciatic nerve block).

Reference: Morgan anesthesia, 6th edition, page no 1000

questions.text: A 5 years old child presents with a limp and pain in the right groin, thigh and knee. On examination, there is decreased abduction and internal rotation. His x-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is an AP pelvic radiograph of a skeletally immature patient of pelvis, both hips and proximal femur showing flattening and deformity of right femoral heads. The most probable diagnosis would be Legg-Calve-Perthes disease (LCPD), but other diagnoses such as infection need to be excluded.

It is an idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral capital epiphysis in children.

The cause is unknown. It is thought to be multifactorial, affecting children between 4-9 years old of low socioeconomic class.

The child is often small with delayed bone age by usually 2 years. It is more common in boys than girls by about 4:1 and it is bilateral in about 20 % of cases.

On x ray, the femoral head is divided into the medial, central and lateral pillars/segments. The central segment is the largest representing 50% of the width with the medial and lateral segment representing 20-30% each.

  • Group A: Normal height of the lateral one-third of the head is maintained. Fragmentation occurs in the central segment of the head.
  • Group B: More than 50% of the original lateral pillar height is maintained.
  • Group C: Less than 50% of the original lateral pillar height is maintained.
  • Group B/C: This group has been added recently to increase the prognostic accuracy of the lateral pillar classification. In this group the lateral pillar is exactly 50% of lateral pillar height is maintained.

It has the best interobserver agreement. Limitation is that final classification is not possible at initial presentation due to the fact that the patient needs to have entered into the fragmentation stage radiographically

REFERENCE: Essential Orthopedics by Manish Kumar,1st edition, Page no 839

choices.text: Episodes of both- Mania and Depression
Episodes of both- hypomania plus depression

questions.text: What is necessary to call it a bipolar 2 disorder?
questions.solution:
Bipolar 2 disorder requires to have at least one hypomanic episode and one episode of depression.

Bipolar 1 is mania and depression.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no. 360

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient examined the electrolytes and obtained the value given below.
S. Na =145 mEq/L
S. K = 5 mEq/L
The fluid belongs to which compartment?
questions.solution:
The major extracellular cation is sodium. Major intracellular cations are potassium.

The major extracellular anion is chloride. Major intracellular anions are phosphate and proteins.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Edition, Pg. 6

questions.text: Serpiginous pattern of skin lesion as shown in the image below is characteristically seen in -
questions.solution:
Serpiginous/serpent-like skin lesions are seen in Cutaneous larva migrans (CLM).

It is caused by various animal hookworm species (e.g., Ancylostoma braziliense), and the parasite is acquired from direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. The parasitic infection usually begins with an inflamed papule, often located between the toes, where the hookworm species (e.g., Ancylostoma braziliense) larvae enter the skin. Serpentine or linear single-track lines later mark the course of the larvae as they migrate through the epidermis of the trunk and lower extremities. Symptoms begin to appear within the first two weeks of the patient's return from a tropical or endemic country, and the erythematous lines can enlarge as much as 1 to 2 cm per day.

Incontinentia pigmenti

Linear lesions along the blaschko lines.

Psoriasis and lichen planus

They are papulo-squamous lesions

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I - Page 33.18 - 33.20

questions.text: A 36 years old male patient is newly diagnosed with HIV. He is prone to develop all of the following malignancies except -
questions.solution:
• HIV infection is associated with an increased risk of certain malignancies due to the weakened immune system.
  • Kaposi sarcoma, a cancer of blood vessels, is more common in HIV-positive individuals.
  • Urogenital cancers, such as cervical and anal cancer, have a higher incidence in people with HIV.
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a type of blood cancer, is more prevalent in HIV-infected individuals.
  • Adult T cell leukemia (ATL) is not typically associated with HIV infection; it is caused by human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1) infection instead.
  • Therefore, the malignancy least likely to be developed by the newly diagnosed HIV patient is adult T cell leukemia (option D).

Reference: Harrison's principal of medicine, 21st edition, page no. 491

questions.text: Which of the following are harvested when performing anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction with a double loop hamstring autograft?
questions.solution:
Because of the availability of long tendons and the minimal donor morbidity associated with the gracilis and semitendinosus tendons, they are currently considered the structures of choice for hamstring tendon autograft anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction by most authors. The gracilis and semitendinosus are beneath and behind the sartorius (not a hamstring) at the tibial insertion of the pes anserinus. They have long tendons and relatively small muscle bellies typical of vestigial muscles (in contrast to the biceps and semimembranosus). With approximately 20 cm of tendon typically available, this allows the double loop technique to provide a graft of sufficient strength.

REFERENCES: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition - Page no. 254 - 256

questions.text: A 6 years old boy presented with small ill-defined hypopigmented macules on cheek. Most likely diagnosis is -
questions.solution:
Pityriasis alba

It is a type of dermatitis

Occurs predominantly in children (3-16 years). Both sexes are equally susceptible.

C/f: Lesion is rounded, oval or irregular plaque, which is red, pink or skin- colored and has fine lamellar or branny scaling.

Initially erythema with minimal scaling, later erythema subsides and only show persistent fine scaling with hypopigmentation. History of atopy present. Sensation intact.

Pityriasis Rosea

It is self-limiting, which resolves in about 6-10 weeks. It is characterized by a large circular or oval "herald patch", usually found on the chest, abdomen, or back.

The herald patch is followed sometime later, typically two weeks or so, by the development of smaller scaly oval red patches, resembling a Christmas tree, distributed mainly on the chest and back. Collarette scale is a characteristic sign in pityriasis rosea. With the edge peripherally attached and lifted up near the center of the lesion.

Pityriasis Versicolor

Superficial fungal infection

Scaly macule shows both hyper- and hypo- pigmentation

Seen on upper trunk and shoulders commonly.

Indeterminate leprosy

Type of leprosy

Non scaly

Epidermal atrophy, wrinkling

Slight erythema or hypo pigmentation

Hypoesthesia

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II -9th Edition, Page no 39.25

questions.text:
A 60 years old male patient is a known case of chronic kidney disease for the last 10 years. He is on hemodialysis 2 times per week. What are the complications of hemodialysis?
A. Hypotension
B. Hypertension
C. Peritonitis
D. Bleeding Tendency
E. Dementia
questions.solution:
Peritonitis is a complication when dialysis is done through peritoneum.

Hypotension and Hypertension occur during hemodialysis due to disturbance in ultrafiltration.

Increased bleeding tendency is due to uremia and the heparin which is used during Hemodialysis.

Patients develop dialysis dementia on long term HD.

Reference: Harrison's principal of medicine, 21st edition, page no.2323

questions.text: In relation to a patient having a cerebral vascular accident such as stroke, reverse cerebral steal phenomenon is mentioned with which of the following induction agents?
questions.solution:
Barbiturates cause cerebral vasoconstriction leading to a reduction in the cerebral blood flow. Because barbiturate-induced cerebral vasoconstriction occurs only in normal areas, these agents tend to redistribute blood flow from normal to ischemic areas in the brain. The cerebral vasculature in ischemic areas remains maximally dilated because of ischemic vasomotor paralysis.

Thus, thiopentone sodium causes preferential perfusion of the focal ischemic areas in the brain, which is known as Robinhood/ reverse cerebral steal phenomenon. But barbiturates are not cerebro-protective in global ischemia.

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical Anaesthesiology 6th edition, Page no 174, 591

choices.text: Have the greatest total cross-sectional area
Have the slowest velocity of blood flow

questions.text: Not true about capillaries -
questions.solution:
Only about 5% of blood volume circulates in capillaries but physiologically this is most significant as exchange of nutrients, gases, water and waste products between the blood and tissues occurs in capillaries. Hence, capillaries are known as exchange vessels.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition Page 568

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of permanent loss of the sense of smell?
questions.solution:
Although loss of smell function has been associated with a number of systemic diseases and metabolic disorders, most patients with such loss fall into one of three major categories: head trauma, upper respiratory infections (eg, influenza and the common cold), and rhinosinusitis. Of these primary causes, upper respiratory infections are the most common. Typically, permanent hyposmia or anosmia occurs after the age of 40 in such individuals. In a study of a large number of consecutive patients seen at the University of Pennsylvania Smell and Taste Center during the period from 1980 to 1986, upper respiratory infections accounted for 26% of the cases, head trauma for 18%, and nasal and sinus disease 15%.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition, page no 568

choices.text: It is malignant hypertension that leads to hypertensive encephalopathy
The initial goal is to reduce mean arterial blood pressure by more than 25% within minutes to 2hrs
Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in arterioles of brain, retina and kidney
IV nitroprusside can be given initially to reduce BP

questions.text: A 56 years old male patient who is a known case of hypertension suddenly becomes unconscious and is taken to hospital by his wife. On admission BP was 220/110 mmHg. Urgent NCCT Brain was done which is normal. On fundus examination hemorrhage and hard exudate is present. On urine examination, protein ++. What is the false statement regarding this patient?
questions.solution:
The syndrome of malignant hypertension is an example of a hypertensive emergency that is associated with an abrupt increase of blood pressure in a patient with underlying hypertension or related to the sudden onset of hypertension in a previously normotensive individual.

The absolute level of blood pressure is not as important as its rate of rise.

Pathologically, the syndrome is associated with diffuse necrotizing vasculitis, arterial thrombi, and fibrin deposition in arteriolar walls. Fibrinoid necrosis has been observed in arterioles of kidney, brain, retina, and other organs.

Clinically, the syndrome is recognized by progressive retinopathy (arteriolar spasm, hemorrhages, exudates, and papilledema), deteriorating renal function with proteinuria, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and encephalopathy.

Historic inquiry should include questions about the use of monoamine oxidase inhibitors and recreational drugs (e.g., cocaine, amphetamines).

In patients with encephalopathy, the initial goal of therapy is to reduce mean arterial blood pressure by no more than 25% within minutes to 2 h or to a blood pressure in the range of 160/100-110 mmHg.

This may be accomplished with IV nitroprusside, a short-acting vasodilator with a rapid onset of action that allows for minute-to-minute control of blood pressure. Parenteral labetalol and nicardipine are also effective agents for the treatment of hypertensive encephalopathy.

In the absence of encephalopathy or another catastrophic event, it is preferable to reduce blood pressure over hours or longer rather than minutes.

Ref. - Harrison's principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2087

choices.text: Injury to the posterior ligamentous complex on MRI
Left leg radiculopathy since the injury
Retropulsion of a vertebral body fragment reducing the spinal canal by 35% with no neurological deficit

questions.text: A 44-year-old electrician falls from a ladder and suffers an isolated L4 fracture. There is anterior wedging of the vertebral body with 40% loss of vertebral height. Which of these associated features would be an indication for operative stabilization?
questions.solution:
Thoracolumbar fractures can be classified according to Denis' three-column theory in combination with the mechanism of injury. Although a two-column injury burst fracture does not necessitate operative stabilization (even with retropulsed fragments), it has been shown that disruption of the posterior ligamentous complex has a high risk of progressing to a late kyphosis with a poor outcome.

Neurological deficit, height loss of more than 50%, and kyphosis greater than 20° are predictors of instability which require surgical intervention.

However, more recent studies have shown that, in addition, the posterior ligamentous complex (PLC) is vital in determining the stability of these types of fractures and whether patients are likely to develop post-traumatic kyphosis with poor outcomes including neurological deficits.

Absolute indications for surgical intervention in thoracolumbar burst fractures are progressive neurological deficit, cauda equina syndrome, and significant spinal instability despite bracing.

Reference: Rockwood and green's fractures in adults 9th edition 2906-2925

questions.text: Which part of the rib develops from the transverse element of lumbar vertebrae?
questions.solution:
• The accessory process of the rib develops from the transverse element of the lumbar vertebrae.
  • The transverse process itself gives rise to various structures in the rib, but specifically, the accessory process is the part that originates from the transverse element of the lumbar vertebrae.
  • The other options (b. Transverse process and c. Mammillary process) are not directly related to the rib's development from the transverse element.

The transverse and costal elements of the vertebrae are as follows:

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page No - 229

questions.text: A 37 years old female patient is a known case of Sjogren syndrome. She is on treatment with oral steroids. She presented to you with complaints of breathlessness on exertion and a progressive dry cough. You suspect ILD in this patient. Which subtype of interstitial lung disease is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Fibrotic NSIP is the most common subtype of ILD seen in patients of Sjogren syndrome.

NSIP is also the most common subtype of ILD seen in patients of Connective tissue disorders. NSIP is also commonly observed in patients with CTD and less frequently with familial interstitial pneumonia, drug toxicity, and infection.

Usual interstitial pneumonia pneumonitis is found in Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and common in RA.

Acute interstitial pneumonia presents as ARDS like illness.

Reference: Harrison's principal of medicine, 21st edition, page no.2195

questions.text: All except one of the following is oral manifestation of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.
questions.solution:
There are at least 40 oral manifestations of HIV infections. They include oral candidiasis, recurrent herpetic and aphthous ulcers, angular cheilitis, hairy leukoplakia, periodontitis, gingivitis, diffuse parotitis, and Kaposi's sarcoma. In children, the most common signs are oral candidiasis, diffuse parotitis, and oral ulcers.

Wickham's striae are interlacing white lines found in lichen planus.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition, page no 1025

choices.text: Origin is from inner, subjective space

questions.text: Regarding pseudo hallucinations, all are true except-
questions.solution:
Hallucinations are perceptions without a stimulus which occur in the external, objective space and are produced without one's will.

Pseudo hallucinations occur in the inner, subjective space and may be recognized as unreal but are not always produced willfully.

Imagery on the other hand occurs willfully.

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology: Signs and Symptoms in Psychiatry, 3rd edition - Page no 28

questions.text: A 45 years old patient complains of decreased urine output, malaise, weight loss and low-grade fever. His Serum Creatinine was 2 mg/dl. He was newly diagnosed with HIV. In HIV, which type of glomerulopathy is seen?
questions.solution:
FSGS refers to a pattern of renal injury characterized by segmental glomerular scars that involve some but not all glomeruli (focal); the clinical findings of FSGS largely manifest as proteinuria.

  • In HIV, the type of glomerulopathy seen is focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).
  • The patient presents with decreased urine output, malaise, weight loss, and low-grade fever.
  • Serum creatinine is elevated at 2 mg/dl.
  • FSGS is a common renal complication in HIV-infected individuals.
  • It is characterized by scarring and damage to specific segments of the glomeruli in the kidneys.
  • HIV-associated FSGS can lead to proteinuria and progressive kidney dysfunction.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2342

questions.text: A local numbing cream is sometimes applied to the skin before attempting an intravenous access in pediatric patients. Which of the following local anesthetics is combined to produce this cream?
questions.solution:
EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics) cream was formulated to overcome the obstacles prevented by intact skin. It consists of a mixture of lidocaine and prilocaine bases in an emulsion. Depth of analgesia (usually <0.5 cm), duration of action (usually <2 h), and amount of drug absorbed depends on application time, dermal blood flow, and total dose administered. Typically, 1 to 2 g of cream is applied per 10-cm2 area of skin. Dermal analgesia sufficient for inserting an intravenous catheter requires about 1 h under an occlusive dressing.

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical Anaesthesiology 6th edition, Page no 267

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions can cause a decrease in platelet production?
I. Vitamin B12 deficiency
II. Myeloproliferative disorders
III. Disseminated intravascular coagulation
IV. Haemolytic uremic syndrome
questions.solution:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation is a condition that causes excessive clotting and platelet consumption, leading to a decrease in platelet count.

Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a condition that causes hemolysis, thrombocytopenia, and kidney failure, but it does not directly affect platelet production.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Edition, Pg. 477-487

questions.text: A 48 years old female is being induced for general anesthesia with propofol. Which of the following effects can be minimized by giving lignocaine earlier to injecting Propofol?
questions.solution:
Propofol produces a 15-25% decrease in the blood pressure (option a) and systemic vascular resistance, without a compensatory increase in the heart rate; the cardiac output decreases by 20%.

Option c: Pain on injection occurs in up to 28% of subjects. The incidence may be reduced by the addition of lidocaine (1 ml of 1%), cooling the drug, and the use of large veins.

Option d: Bolus administration of propofol produces apnoea of variable duration (30 to ≥60 seconds) and suppression of laryngeal reflexes. Infusion of the drug produces a decrease in the tidal volume, tachypnoea, and a depressed ventilatory response to hypercarbia and hypoxia.

Reference: Drugs in Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, Edward Scarth, Susan Smith 5th edition, Page no 326.

questions.text: Pathergy test is positive in all except -
questions.solution:
Pathergy test is altered tissue reactivity that occurs in response to minor trauma.

Positive in Behcets disease, Sweet syndrome and Pyoderma gangrenosum.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 49.1-49.5

questions.text: A 54 years old female patient suddenly became unconscious. In emergency room her BP was 200/110 mmHg. NCCT Brain shows intraparenchymal hemorrhage and CXR is normal. She was intubated and put on ventilator. After 2 days she develops right lower zone consolidation on CXR. What organism is most commonly responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
• The most common organism causing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is Acinetobacter, followed by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and MRSA.
  • VAP can be caused by both multidrug-resistant (MDR) and non-MDR bacterial pathogens.
  • Acinetobacter is particularly problematic as an MDR pathogen in healthcare settings.
  • Fungal and viral pathogens may rarely cause VAP in severely immunocompromised patients.

Reference: Harrison's principal of medicine, 21st edition, page no.1016

questions.text: An 85 years old female patient presented with seizure followed by altered sensorium since day one. She is a known case of HTN since 20 years on triple drug combination. On blood investigation she had Sodium of 110 mEq/L. Patient was treated with 3% NaCl and now the patient has become unconscious and has developed quadriparesis. Her MRI brain was done which is shown below. Identify the given image.
questions.solution:
OSMOTIC DEMYELINATION SYNDROME (CENTRAL PONTINE MYELINOLYSIS)

This disorder often presents in a devastating fashion as quadriplegia and pseudobulbar palsy, although less severe presentations may occur.

Predisposing factors include severe underlying medical illness or nutritional deficiency; most cases are associated with rapid correction of hyponatremia or with hyperosmolar states, and clinical symptoms are usually identified a few days after sodium correction.

Previously termed central pontine myelinolysis, the more accurate term osmotic demyelination syndrome is now preferred. The pathology consists of demyelination without inflammation in the base of the pons, with relative sparing of axons and nerve cells.

MRI is useful in establishing the diagnosis and may also identify partial forms that present as confusion, dysarthria, and/or disturbances of conjugate gaze without quadriplegia.

Occasional cases present with lesions outside of the brainstem. Therapy for the restoration of severe hyponatremia should aim for gradual correction, i.e., by ≤8 mmol/L (8 meq/L) within 24 h and 15 mmol/L (15 meq/L) within 48 h.

Reference: Harrison's principal of medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2273

questions.text: Given below is the initial radiograph of a 19-year-old man who sustained a closed clavicle fracture, shows postoperative radiographs. If the patient had been treated non surgically, what is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Recent studies comparing surgical treatment with nonsurgical management in displaced clavicle fractures have revealed a decreased rate of malunion and nonunion with surgery. In addition, significant malunions can lead to functional deficits at the shoulder. Thus, with open reduction and internal fixation and anatomic or near-anatomic reduction, there should be a higher likelihood of normal shoulder strength and function. Infection and local sensory deficits would not be expected with nonsurgical management, whereas surgical treatment has a small risk of infection and a high likelihood of sensory deficits from iatrogenic damage to the supraclavicular nerves.

REFERENCES: Apley's System Of Orthopaedics And Fractures - 10th Edition - Pg 755, 756, 757

choices.text: The integrity of the skull base
Differentiation of soft tissue and retained mucus

questions.text: Radiographic imaging of sinus neoplasia with computed tomography (CT) provides information regarding all of the following except -
questions.solution:
With CT, one has difficulty distinguishing between retained secretions and tumor or and swollen mucosa. Magnetic resonance imaging complements CT by providing valuable information in the differentiation of normal mucosa from neoplasm and neoplasm from retained mucus.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition, page no 812

questions.text: All of the followings are true about lower motor neuron paralysis, except -
questions.solution:
• Lower motor neuron paralysis is a condition that occurs when there is damage or dysfunction to the lower motor neurons, which are responsible for transmitting nerve impulses from the spinal cord to the muscles.
  • In lower motor neuron paralysis, the Babinski sign is typically negative. A positive Babinski sign is indicative of an upper motor neuron lesion in the corticospinal tract.

Other options:

  • The tone in the affected muscles is decreased or lost, leading to hypotonia (reduced muscle tone).
  • There is a loss of muscle tone and weakness, leading to flaccid (limp) paralysis. This means the affected muscles cannot contract properly
  • The lower motor neuron damage disrupts the reflex arc, leading to the absence of tendon reflexes. When a tendon is stretched, a normal reflex response would cause the muscle to contract, but in this case, that response is diminished or absent.

Difference between upper and lower motor type of paralysis

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 4, 8th Edition, Page No - 51

questions.text: A 35 years old man is convinced that his wife is having an extra marital affair with her boss. He hired a detective to spy on her and despite the spy telling him that there is no such thing, he is still not convinced. He is otherwise normal with his thought process and goes to work regularly. This is likely to be-
questions.solution:
In Persistent Delusional disorder, the psychopathology is at the level of only thought content which in this case is morbid jealousy or infidelity.

In the rest of the spheres of his life the person is able to function normally.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry 11th Edition - Page no 2626

questions.solution:
Schatzker classification of proximal tibial fractures -

Type I - Lateral split fracture

Type III - Central Pure depression fracture

Type VI - Metaphyseal-diaphyseal disassociation

Action potential with plateau in visceral tissue
Action potential without plateau in uterus tissue
Action potential with plateau in ureter tissue

questions.text: Prolonged depolarization accounts for the sustained contraction of smooth muscle. The given graph belongs to what type of tissue?
questions.solution:
Calcium influx occurs into the smooth muscle cell. There is binding of calcium with calmodulin dependent MLCK. Then phosphorylation of myosin occurs which leads to increased myosin ATPase activity. Myosin binds with actin resulting in cross bridge formation, which leads to contraction of smooth muscle.

Reference : Fundamentals of Medical physiology by L Prakasam Reddy, 7th edition, Pg. No. - 88

questions.text: An 18-year-old comes to you for the first time after moving from a remote area with limited medical care. He has a history of multiple severe bacterial infections and albinism. A representative peripheral blood smear is shown in the Figure given below. What diagnosis is most consistent with this history and blood smear?
questions.solution:
• Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by defects in the lysosomal transport protein LYST, encoded by the CHS1 gene at 1q42.
  • The syndrome is characterized by large granules in neutrophils and other cells containing lysosomes, leading to systemic manifestations.
  • Patients with CHS may present with nystagmus, partial oculocutaneous albinism, and an increased susceptibility to infections caused by various bacterial agents.
  • In childhood, some CHS patients may develop an "accelerated phase" with hemophagocytic syndrome and an aggressive lymphoma that might require bone marrow transplantation.
  • CHS neutrophils and monocytes show impaired chemotaxis and microbial killing due to slow fusion rates of lysosomal granules with phagosomes. Natural killer (NK) cell function is also affected.
  • Severe disabling peripheral neuropathy can occur in adulthood in CHS patients.

Other options:

  • Pelger-Huet anomaly is a benign disorder characterized by bilobed granulocytes with a spectacle-like nucleus.
  • Kostmann syndrome is a severe neutropenia condition with almost complete absence of neutrophils and neutrophil precursors, often caused by mutations in the anti-apoptosis gene HAX-1.
  • Acute leukemia presents with a uniform population of primitive myeloblasts with immature chromatin, nucleoli in some cells, and primary cytoplasmic granules.

Reference: Harrison's principal of medicine, 21st edition, page no. 447

questions.text: The anterior axillary group of lymph nodes lie along which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
The nodes of the anterior (pectoral) group lie along the lateral thoracic vessels. It is present along with the lower border of the pectoralis minor.

They receive lymph from the upper half of the anterior wall of the trunk, and from the major part of the breast.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page No - 58

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the chapter of Obsessive compulsive and related disorders in DSM 5?
questions.solution:
OCRD includes-

  • Trichotillomania
  • Hoarding Disorder
  • Skin Picking Disorder
  • Body Dysmorphic Disorder

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no 422

questions.text: All of the following mitochondrial diseases are sporadic and somatic except?
questions.solution:
• Mitochondrial diseases are a group of disorders caused by defects in the mitochondria, leading to impaired energy production and affecting various organs.
  • Sporadic mitochondrial diseases are caused by random mutations that occur during a person's lifetime and are not inherited from their parents.
  • Somatic mitochondrial diseases are those in which the mutation only affects certain tissues or cells, not all cells in the body.
  • NARP (Neuropathy, Ataxia, and Retinitis Pigmentosa) is not sporadic or somatic; it is a maternally inherited mitochondrial disease caused by a specific mutation in mitochondrial DNA.
  • In NARP, the affected individual inherits the mitochondrial DNA mutation from their mother, leading to a wide range of neurological and visual symptoms.

Other options:

  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (PEO) is a sporadic mitochondrial disease characterized by weakness in the eye muscles, leading to difficulty in moving the eyes.
  • Pearson's syndrome is also sporadic and affects multiple organs, causing sideroblastic anemia, pancreatic insufficiency, and kidney problems.
  • Kearns-Sayre syndrome is another sporadic mitochondrial disease that affects multiple systems, leading to symptoms like progressive external ophthalmoplegia, heart block, and pigmentary retinopathy.

questions.text: Sign and symptoms of ataxia, tremors, chorea-athetosis type of movements in a patient of thalamic syndrome are due to the involvement of which of the following nucleus/nuclei?
questions.solution:
The ventral anterior nucleus influences the activities of the motor cortex and is involved in planning and initiating movements. It is also involved in transmitting the cortical recruiting response.

The ventrolateral nucleus is active during both passive and active movement of the contralateral part of the body and also has a role in relaying motor feedback from the cerebellum to the cerebral cortex.

choices.text: Immediate rate control with B blocker
Urgent transesophageal echocardiography to see LA clot and anticoagulation

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient is a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism. He presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of breathlessness within 1 hour. ECG was done, as shown below. On examination, the patient has tachycardia and BP 80/60 mmHg, chest auscultation suggests bilateral lower zone fine crepitations. Which is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has Atrial Fibrillation (AF)

The treatment and management of the patient with AF centers on three aims:

  • control of patient symptoms through a strategy of rate control and/or rhythm control;
  • appropriate mitigation of thromboembolism risk; and
  • addressing modifiable risk factors for progression of AF.

In the acute onset of AF, if significant hemodynamic compromise, pulmonary edema, or evidence of coronary ischemia is present, emergent cardioversion is recommended.

Electrical cardioversion can be achieved with a QRS synchronous shock, preferably in a sedated patient, or via pharmacologic cardioversion, most typically with the intravenous administration of the class III antiarrhythmic drug.

In the hemodynamically stable patient with new-onset AF, therapy should focus on control of ventricular rate to prevent hemodynamic sequelae, consideration of anticoagulation to mitigate thromboembolic risk, and consideration of restoration and maintenance of sinus rhythm-a so-called rhythm control strategy.

It is presumed that if the presenting episode of AF is >48 h or if the episode duration is unknown, there is risk for precipitating a thromboembolic complication through cardioversion, whether electrical or pharmacologically achieved. Therefore, in this circumstance, the patient should be either initiated on anticoagulation, with cardioversion deferred for at least 4 weeks after uninterrupted anticoagulation, or evaluated to exclude the presence of left atrial appendage thrombus. Most commonly, transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is used to evaluate for left atrial appendage thrombus, although computed tomography (CT) angiography has been demonstrated to have excellent sensitivity and specificity as well.

Reference: Harrison's principal of medicine, 21st edition, page no 1905

choices.text: Bedsheets should be washed in water hotter than 130°F
Use of a humidifier can decrease dust mite levels in houses
Dust mites can be directly killed using commercially available products

questions.text: Which of the following statements are not true about dust mite avoidance?
questions.solution:
A variety of measures can be taken by patients with dust mite allergy. Measures to reduce exposure to dust mites concentrate on the bedding.

These include replacing feather pillows and bedspreads with synthetic ones that can be washed in hot water.

Covering mattresses with small-pore plastic sheeting is beneficial.

Removing carpets and frequent vacuuming also help.

Acaricidal products can directly kill mites.

Maintaining a relative humidity (RH) of less than 50% is one recommendation for reducing the number of house dust mites and their allergens in homes. A recent study showed that allergen levels were more than 10 times lower in low-RH homes compared with humid homes and suggested that it is possible to maintain an indoor RH of less than 51% during the humid summer season.

Hence, dehumidifiers are effective tools in dust mite control.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no 721

questions.text: Pulse oximetry involves non-invasive measurement of the oxygen saturation of blood. A false increase in reading can be caused by -
questions.solution:
Inaccuracy may result from excessive ambient light, movement artifact, poor peripheral perfusion, electrical interference, venous congestion, and when SaO2 is less than 80% (as calibration data below this level are extrapolated). Response time to detecting desaturation varies with probe location (e.g., up to 30-60 s with a finger probe). Colored nail polish may produce inaccuracies (tend to increase readings).

Effects of other pigments:

  • Carboxyhemoglobin: most is counted as HbO, thus SpO2 is falsely high.
  • Methemoglobin and bilirubin: counted as Hb, thus SpO2 is falsely low (but may be falsely high if true saturation is very low, i.e., < 70%).
  • Methylthioninium chloride (methylene blue), indo-cyanine green, etc.: may temporarily decrease SpO2 for a few minutes after iv injection.
  • Fetal hemoglobin, polycythaemia: no effect.

questions.text: Bispectral index is used to monitor -
questions.solution:
Bispectral index

Cerebral function monitor that uses a processed EEG obtained from a single frontal electrode to provide a measure of cerebral activity. Used to monitor anesthetic depth in an attempt to prevent awareness. Produces a dimensionless number (the BIS number) ranging from 100 (fully awake) to 0 (no cerebral activity). The algorithm used to calculate the BIS value is commercially protected but is based on power spectral analysis of the EEG, the synchrony of slow and fast wave activity and the burst suppression ratio. Targeting a BIS number of 40-60 is advocated to reduce awareness and allow more rapid emergence from anesthesia, although the evidence does not support its routine use.

HRCT Thorax is always abnormal shows Bilateral patchy Ground glass opacity

questions.text: A 28 years old male patient recently started cigarette smoking. After several days of it he started developing dyspnea, cough, malaise and night sweats. His ESR and CRP were raised. CXR suggests B/L lower zone haziness. BAL shows Eosinophils>25%. He is diagnosed with acute eosinophilic pneumonia. What is the true statement regarding this disease?
questions.solution:
• Acute eosinophilic pneumonia is associated with recent cigarette smoking or exposure to other environmental stimuli.
  • It predominantly affects males aged 20 to 40 with no history of asthma.
  • Peripheral eosinophilia may not be present at presentation, but eosinophils >25% are seen in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid.
  • High fevers, basilar rales, and rhonchi on forced expiration are common physical examination findings.
  • HRCT thorax shows bilateral random patchy ground-glass or reticular opacities and small pleural effusions in most patients.
  • Pleural fluid analysis shows high pH and marked eosinophilia.
  • The condition has an excellent prognosis, and most patients respond well to corticosteroid therapy.
  • Complete clinical and radiographic recovery occurs within several weeks of starting treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is/are involved in the regulation of renal blood flow?
questions.solution:
Renal blood flow is regulated by a combination of factors including autoregulation, the sympathetic nervous system, and the RAAS (renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system).

Autoregulation ensures that renal blood flow remains relatively constant within a certain range of mean arterial pressure.

The sympathetic nervous system and the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system can alter renal blood flow in response to changes in blood volume and pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an AIDS defining illness?
questions.solution:
• Tertiary syphilis is not an AIDS-defining illness.
  • AIDS-defining illnesses are specific conditions that indicate a severe weakening of the immune system due to HIV infection.
  • Examples of AIDS-defining illnesses include lymphoma of the brain, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, and extrapulmonary cryptococcosis.
  • Tertiary syphilis, though a serious condition, is not considered one of the defining illnesses for AIDS. It is a late stage of syphilis infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum.
  • The presence of AIDS-defining illnesses is an important criterion for diagnosing AIDS in HIV-infected individuals.

questions.text: A 60 years old non-diabetic male patient is CKD stage 4. He develops peripheral neuropathy due to chronic kidney disease. What is a false statement regarding CKD induced peripheral neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Peripheral neuropathy usually becomes clinically evident after the patient reaches stage 4 CKD, although electrophysiologic and histologic evidence occurs earlier.

Initially, sensory nerves are involved more than motor, lower extremities more than the upper, and distal parts of the extremities more than the proximal.

The "restless leg syndrome" is characterized by ill-defined sensations of sometimes debilitating discomfort in the legs and feet relieved by frequent leg movement.

Evidence of peripheral neuropathy without another cause (e.g., diabetes mellitus or iron deficiency) is an indication for starting renal replacement therapy.

Many of the complications described above will resolve with dialysis, although subtle nonspecific abnormalities may persist.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding acute lymphoblastic lymphoma (ALL) is true?
questions.solution:
• Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from hematopoietic progenitors in bone marrow or lymphatic system, leading to an increase of immature nonfunctioning leukemic cells.
  • Bone marrow infiltration causes anemia, granulocytopenia, and thrombocytopenia, resulting in fatigue, weakness, infection, and hemorrhages.
  • Some congenital chromosomal abnormalities increase the risk of acute leukemia, such as Klinefelter syndrome, Fanconi anemia, Bloom syndrome, ataxia telangiectasia, neurofibromatosis, and Down syndrome.
  • Genetic predisposition, even without an associated inherited disease, may increase the risk of acute leukemia, as seen in identical twins of leukemic children.
  • Examination of cerebrospinal fluid is crucial for ALL diagnosis due to the high risk of central nervous system (CNS) involvement.
  • Adult ALLs are mostly of B-cell origin (70%), while 25% belong to the T-cell lineage.
  • BCR-ABL1-like ALL has genetic similarities to Ph+ ALL and can be treated with BCR-ABL inhibitors (e.g., dasatinib) or JAK2 inhibitors (e.g., ruxolitinib).

Reference: Harrison’s principal of medicine, 21st edition, page no 829

choices.text: Platelets circulate with an average life span of 2-3 days
The major regulator of platelet production is the hormone (TPO), which is synthesized mainly from Bone marrow
A reduction in platelet and megakaryocyte mass increases the level of TPO

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding platelets?
questions.solution:
Platelets are released from megakaryocytes, likely under the influence of flow in the capillary sinuses.

The normal blood platelet count is 150,000–450,000/μL. The major regulator of platelet production is the hormone thrombopoietin (TPO), which is synthesized in the liver and other organs.

Synthesis is increased with inflammation and specifically by interleukin 6.

TPO binds to its receptor on platelets and megakaryocytes, by which it is removed from the circulation. Thus, a reduction in platelet and megakaryocyte mass increases the level of TPO, which then stimulates platelet production.

Platelets circulate with an average life span of 7–10 days. Approximately one-third of the platelets reside in the spleen, and this number increases in proportion to splenic size

questions.text: A 29 years old female patient had a pathological fracture of her clavicle and ribs. Her X-ray shows subperiosteal resorption of the 2nd and 3rd metatarsals and phalanges. On Blood investigations, hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia are seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The distinctive bone manifestation of hyperparathyroidism is osteitis fibrosa cystica, which occurred in 10-25% of patients in series reported 50 years ago.

Histologically, the pathognomonic features are an increase in the giant multinucleated osteoclasts in scalloped areas on the surface of the bone (Howship's lacunae) and a replacement of the normal cellular and marrow elements by fibrous tissue.

X-ray changes include resorption of the phalangeal tufts and replacement of the usually sharp cortical outline of the bone in the digits by an irregular outline (subperiosteal resorption).

In recent years, osteitis fibrosa cystica is very rare in primary hyperparathyroidism, probably due to the earlier detection of the disease.


In Osteomalacia, Calcium and Phosphorus levels are low due to Vit. D deficiency.

questions.text: There are more than 400 blood groups. But only ABO blood groups are considered in matching. All are true regarding ABO blood groups except -
questions.solution:
Preformed ABO antibodies are present in person’s serum, when his RBC’s lacks the corresponding antigen.

In other blood groups, preformed antibodies are not present.

The ABO blood group system is important because essentially all individuals produce antibodies to the ABH carbohydrate antigen that they lack.

The major blood groups of this system are A, B, AB and O. O type RBCs lack A and B both antigens.

These antigens are carbohydrates attached to a precursor backbone, and may be found on cellular membrane either as glycosphingolipids or glycoproteins and are secreted into plasma and body fluids as a glycoprotein.

In most people, A and B antigens are secreted by the cells and are present in the circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following interventions have been effective in improving symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and graded exercise therapy (GET) have been found to be the only beneficial interventions in chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS). Some patient groups argue against these approaches because of the implication that CFS is a purely mental disorder.

CBT is a psychotherapeutic approach directed at changing unhealthy disease perpetuating patterns of thoughts and behaviors. It includes educating the patient about the etiologic model, setting goals, restoring fixed bedtimes and wake-up times, challenging and changing fatigue and activity-related concerns, reducing a focus on symptoms, spreading activities evenly throughout the day, gradually increasing physical activity, planning a return to work, and resuming other activities.

The intervention, which typically consists of 12–14 sessions spread over 6 months, helps CFS patients gain control over their symptoms. GET targets deconditioning and exercise intolerance and usually involves a home exercise program that continues for 3–5 months. Walking or cycling is systematically increased, with set goals for maximal heart rates.

CBT and GET appear to improve fatigue primarily by changing the patient’s perception of the fatigue and also by reducing the focus on symptoms. In general, CBT studies tend to yield better improvement rates than GET trials. Not all patients benefit from CBT or GET.

Predictors of poor outcome are medical (including psychiatric) comorbidities, current disability claims, and severe pain. CBT offered in an early stage of the illness reduces the burden of CFS for the patient as well as for society in terms of decreased medical and disability-related costs.

Full recovery from untreated CFS is rare: the median annual recovery rate is 5% (range, 0–31%), and the median improvement rate is 39% (range, 8–63%).

Patients with an underlying psychiatric disorder and those who continue to attribute their symptoms to an undiagnosed medical condition have poorer outcomes. The other listed therapies have been tried in patients with CFS with no proven lasting benefit.

Reference: Harrison’s principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, page no 3534

questions.text: A 16 years old type-1 diabetes mellitus patient was on continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion. While on holiday with her family she became disoriented. However, there is no need for hypertonic saline as correction of hyperglycemia by insulin shall suffice in managing hyponatremia.

Hypertonic saline is only given in acute onset hyponatremia with neurological features.

choices.text: Family history of sudden cardiac death

questions.text: A 20 years old patient has been diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following is not a risk factor for sudden death in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a condition characterized by abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, which can lead to various cardiac issues, including sudden death.
  • The following are risk factors for sudden death in patients with HCM:
    1. Spontaneous non-sustained ventricular tachycardia: These are short bursts of rapid, abnormal heart rhythms originating from the ventricles (lower chambers of the heart) that can be a warning sign of potential complications.
    2. Spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia: This is a more prolonged and potentially life-threatening abnormal heart rhythm originating from the ventricles.
    3. If there is a history of sudden death in close relatives due to cardiac issues, it can increase the risk for the affected individual.
  • However, atrial fibrillation is not considered a direct risk factor for sudden death in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
  • Atrial fibrillation is a common heart rhythm disorder, but its association with an increased risk of sudden death is not as prominent as the other factors mentioned above in HCM patients.

Reference: Harrison’s principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, page no1972

questions.text: Glycosaminoglycan present in embryonic tissue is
questions.solution:
Hyaluronic acid consists of an unbranched chain of repeating disaccharide units containing GlcUA and GlcNAc.

It is present in bacteria and is found in the ECM of nearly all animal tissues, but is especially high in concentration in highly hydrated types such as skin and umbilical cord, and in bone, cartilage, joints (synovial fluid) and in vitreous humor in the eye, as well as in embryonic tissues.

It is thought to play an important role in permitting cell migration during morphogenesis and wound repair. Its ability to attract water into the ECM triggers loosening of the matrix, aiding this process.

questions.text:
Arrange the following study designs in increasing order of their location on the new evidence pyramid:
A. Cohort study
B. Systematic reviews and meta-analyses
C. Case-control studies
D. Randomized control trials
questions.solution:
• The correct order of study designs in increasing order of their location on the new evidence pyramid is: Case-control studies (C) < Cohort study (A) < Randomized control trials (D) < Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (B)
  • Case-control studies (C) are lower on the evidence pyramid as they are observational and retrospective.
  • Cohort studies (A) are higher as they are prospective and follow individuals over time.
  • Randomized control trials (D) are even higher as they are experimental and involve random assignment.
  • Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (B) are at the top, as they provide the highest level of evidence by summarizing multiple studies.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 26th Edition - page no. 70

choices.text: It is an important step to control postpartum hemorrhage during c-section
To preserve future fertility and menstrual functions U/L ligation done instead of B/L artery ligation.
Internal iliac artery ligation can be tried if uterine artery ligation fails to control PPH
Anatomically uterine artery crosses ureter anteriorly 2 cm lateral to cervix

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding uterine artery ligation?
questions.solution:
Uterine artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery. From its origin, it enters the broad ligament, runs downwards and medially, crosses the ureter from anteriorly (water under bridge) 2 cm lateral to cervix, gives cervicovaginal branch (supply lower cervix and upper vagina), then from the level of cervix it travels upwards and gives

  • ARCUATE artery: crosses within myometrium and anastomosis in midline supplies OUTER 1/3 of myometrium.
  • RADIAL artery: originates from right angle of arcuate artery, travels inward to supply INNER 2/3 of myometrium. it divides upon reaching endometrium
  • BASAL/straight artery: supplies BASAL layer of ENDOMETRIUM
  • SPIRAL/coiled artery: supplies FUNCTIONALIS/superficial layer of endometrium.

The ovarian artery is a direct branch of the aorta and enters the broad ligament through the infundibulopelvic ligament, Ovarian artery along its course supplies fallopian tubes and towards the uterine cornu it forms an anastomosis with the ovarian branch of the uterine artery. This dual uterine blood supply creates a vascular reserve to prevent uterine ischemia if ligation of the uterine or internal iliac artery is performed to control postpartum hemorrhage.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th Edition, Page no. 23

questions.text: Which of the following free radicals is generated by the Fenton reaction?
questions.solution:
Transition metals such as iron and copper donate or accept free electrons during intracellular reactions and catalyze free radical formation, as in the Fenton reaction (H2O2 + Fe2+ → Fe3+ + OH + OH−).

Option A: O2 • is produced by incomplete reduction of O2 during oxidative phosphorylation; by phagocyte oxidase in leukocytes.

Option B: ONOO- is produced by interaction of O2 • and NO generated by NO synthase in many cell types (endothelial cells, leukocytes, neurons, etc.).

Option C: H2O2 is generated by superoxide dismutase from O2 • and by oxidases in peroxisomes.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 52

questions.text: Which of the following mitochondrial enzymes is involved in the metabolism of Omeprazole?
questions.solution:
CYP2D6

Metabolizes nearly 20% drugs including tricyclic antidepressants, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, many neuroleptics, antiarrhythmics, codeine, debrisoquine, metoprolol.

CYP2C8/9

Important in the biotransformation of commonly used drugs including phenytoin, carbamazepine, warfarin which are narrow safety margin drugs.

CYP2C19

Metabolizes frequently used drugs including omeprazole, lansoprazole, phenytoin, diazepam. Omeprazole and fluconazole are its inhibitors.

CYP1A1/2

Though this subfamily participates in the Metabolism of only few drugs like theophylline, caffeine, paracetamol, carbamazepine, it is more important for activation of procarcinogens.

CYP2E1

It catalyzes oxidation of alcohol, halothane, and formation of minor metabolites of few drugs, notably the hepatotoxic N-acetyl benzoquinoneimine from paracetamol; chronic alcoholism induces this isoenzyme.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no 29

questions.text: A 3rd year student was posted in the microbiology department, where he visited the museum of the department. There was an image of the cell wall of bacteria. Gram negative cell wall contains
questions.solution:
Peptidoglycan layer of gram-positive bacteria is thick and contains teichoic acid, while in gram negative bacteria it is thin and does not contain teichoic acid.

Lipopolysaccharide is found in the outer membrane of the cell wall, not in the cell wall itself.

questions.text: All of the following are part of damage control surgery except -
questions.solution:
• Damage control surgery is a surgical strategy used in critically ill patients to stabilize and manage life-threatening injuries and conditions.
  • It involves a staged approach to surgical intervention with the primary goal of achieving immediate control of hemorrhage and contamination, rather than definitive repair.
    • It includes :

    • Control sepsis
    • Protect from further injury

choices.text: Enlarge the operative wound and lift the nucleus with a lens loop.
Close the eye and refer the patient to a vitreoretinal specialist.

Perform an anterior and middle vitrectomy and remove the nucleus and other cataract debris with the vitrector.

questions.text: Early in the sculpting phase of a routine cataract phacoemulsification, the entire remaining nucleus drops posteriorly onto the retina. What is the best course of action?
questions.solution:
A patient with a dropped nucleus should be referred to a vitreoretinal specialist for further management. An anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) can be placed in the eye by the cataract surgeon during the cataract operation.

questions.text: A mother is worried for her 12 years old daughter. She is short stature. Has shield chest and webbed neck. Which of the following is associated with her?
questions.solution:
Clinically silent cardiac defects, mainly bicuspid aortic valve but also ascending aortic dilation, coarctation of the aorta, and partial anomalous pulmonary venous connections, are present in patients with Turner syndrome.

Short stature, the cardinal finding in virtually all girls with Turner syndrome.

When the ovaries were examined by ultrasonography, older studies found a significant decrease in percentage of detectable ovaries from infancy to later childhood.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins are phosphorylated using protein kinase in prokaryotic Organisms?
questions.solution:
Protein kinases phosphorylate proteins by catalyzing transfer of the terminal phosphoryl group of ATP to the hydroxyl groups of seryl, threonyl, or tyrosyl residues, forming O-phosphoserine, O-phosphothreonine, or O-phosphotyrosine residues, respectively The commonest site of phosphorylation in a protein chain is Serine and Threonine followed by Tyrosine.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated Biochemistry 30th edition, page 93

choices.text: Absence of tenesmus and abdominal tenderness

questions.text: All of the following feature help differentiate cholera from food poisoning except:
questions.solution:
Stools in cholera are copious, rice watery and inoffensive, while those in food poisoning may contain mucus and blood and may be offensive (option A).

Tenesmus and abdominal tenderness are classically absent in cholera, while they may be present in food poisoning (option B).

Muscle cramps in cholera are constant and severe, while they tend to be less constant in food poisoning (option D).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page 263

questions.text: All of the following are indications of amnioinfusion except
questions.solution:
Amnioinfusion in patients with oligohydramnios is not a simple procedure. The needle should be advanced slowly with continuous ultrasound visualization and when its tip has reached the interface between the fetus and the membranes, a warmed saline solution should be infused.

In the majority of cases, 250-350 ml of saline solution will be necessary to achieve optimal ultrasound transmission and perform a careful level II examination. A normal fetus will swallow the infused fluid, and its bladder will be easily seen with ultrasound after 20 minutes. The bladder will not be seen in fetuses with renal agenesis.

Before ending the amnioinfusion, 1 ml of indigo carmine is injected inside the amniotic sac. The patient is instructed to wear a tampon for a few hours following the procedure and observe for evidence of blue discoloration. This finding will confirm the presence of PROM.”

Saline is infused at 37°C. 250 ml of saline is infused in 30 minutes.

Intrauterine resting pressure should not be more than 25 mm of Hg at any time during infusion.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 24th edition, Page no. 1044, 1045

questions.text:
Pointed cell in the following image shows intracellular accumulation of which

Substance?
questions.solution:
Image shows cholesterol-laden macrophages (foam cells, arrow) in a focus of gallbladder cholesterolosis.

Option A: The glycogen masses appear as clear vacuoles within the cytoplasm because glycogen dissolves in aqueous fixatives.

Option B: Intracellular accumulations of proteins usually appear as rounded, eosinophilic droplets, vacuoles, or aggregates in the cytoplasm.

Option C: The term hyaline usually refers to an alteration within cells or in the extracellular space that gives a homogeneous, glassy, pink appearance in routine histologic sections stained with H&E.

Increase in H1 mediated gastrin secretion

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the actions of H3 receptor agonists
questions.solution:
H3 receptors act as presynaptic receptors and decrease the release of histamine and other neurotransmitters.

These antagonize H1 mediated wakefulness and bronchoconstriction. These also decrease gastrin release and produce negative chronotropic effects.

questions.text: The type of receptors present on T cells are -
questions.solution:
CD markers

Lymphocytes and other leukocytes have a number of surface antigen or marker – leukocyte differentiation antigen.

A particular lymphocyte differentiation antigen has been given a CD (cluster of differentiation) number on the basis of its reaction with a cluster of monoclonal antibodies.

These markers reflect the stage of differentiation and functional properties of cell

  1. CD1 – Thymocyte, Langerhans cells
  2. CD 2 – T cell SRBC receptor
  3. CD 3 – T cell antigen receptor complex
  4. CD 4 – Helper T cell

questions.text: Electrospun Poly (Caprolactone) fibers are used for -
questions.solution:
• Electrospun Poly (Caprolactone) fibers are used for tendon reconstruction (c).
  • Electrospinning is a technique used to create nanofibers from various materials, including Poly (Caprolactone) (PCL).
  • They can be used as scaffolds to support the growth and regeneration of damaged or injured tendons, as they provide a 3D structure that mimics the native tendon environment, promoting cell attachment, proliferation, and tissue formation, ultimately aiding in tendon repair and reconstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following risk factors is probably the least significant for the development of a primary open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
• Least significant risk factor for primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is hypermetropia (farsightedness).
  • More significant risk factors for POAG include elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), age, race (more common in black individuals), family history, and myopia (nearsightedness).
  • Other factors like diabetes, anti-VEGF therapy, contraceptive pills, and vascular diseases may also be associated with increased risk of glaucoma.

Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 350

choices.text: Inspiratory phase of breathing is prolonged
Peak flow is impaired and reversed by bronchodilators
Wheeze is not seen in children under 2 years of age

questions.text: In children with bronchiolitis which one of the following statements is true
questions.solution:
Bronchiolitis is associated with narrowing of passages in expiration and hence, prolongation of expiratory phase. This causes breathlessness.

Wheeze is a common presenting feature in young children.

Because of prolonged expiration, peak expiratory flow rate is impaired.

Bronchodilators help broaden the airway and hence improves the expiratory flow.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 2045

questions.text: What is MERMER?
questions.solution:
Brain fingerprinting

Brain fingerprinting was invented by Lawrence Farwell.

It is a technique that uses electro- encephalography (EEG) to determine whether specific information is stored in a subject's brain by measuring electrical brain waves and recording a brain response known as a P300-MERMER (memory and encoding related multifaceted electroencephalographic response) in response to words, phrases, or pictures that are presented on a computer screen.

Reference: The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, Page 446

questions.text: The WHO MONICA project is associated with which of the following
questions.solution:
The reasons for the changing trends in coronary heart disease (CHD) are not precisely known. The WHO has completed a project known as MONICA "(multinational monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular diseases)'' to elucidate this issue. Forty-one centers in 26 countries were participating in this project, which was planned to continue for a 10 years period ending in 1994.

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page 397

questions.text: Hegar's sign of pregnancy is -
questions.solution:
Hegar’s sign is present in 2/3rd cases and is demonstrated between 6-10 weeks.

The sign is based on the fact that - upper part of the body is enlarged by the growing fetus whereas lower part of the body of the uterus, i.e., isthmus is empty and soft and cervix is comparatively firm. Because of these variations in consistency- on bimanual examination, the abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to oppose below body of the uterus.

questions.text: A 28 years old chronic alcoholic female weighing 68 kg is admitted to the emergency department having consumed 20 tablets of 650 mg of paracetamol. A serum paracetamol level is reported as 550 micrograms/ml. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the above condition?
questions.solution:
Ingestion of 13g of paracetamol will result in acute poisoning.

Chances of death and fulminant hepatic failure are high if the plasma levels are above the line joining 200 μg/ml at 4 hours and 30μg/ml at 15 hours. Gastric lavage and activated charcoal at 6 hours will not be effective because most of the drug would have been absorbed by this time.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no 223

questions.text: Crystal violet blood agar is used for which bacteria?
questions.solution:
Crystal violet blood agar is a selective medium for isolation of B hemolytic group A streptococcus. Crystal violet permits the growth of streptococcus but inhibits growth of other gram-positive bacteria (including staphylococcus).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, Tenth edition, Page no 114

questions.text: In the hydatid cyst classification, 'bag of wool' is seen at which stage?
questions.solution:
• In hydatid cyst classification, the 'bag of wool' appearance is seen at stage CE4 (d).
  • CE4 stands for Cystic Echinococcosis stage 4, which is an intermediate stage in the development of a hydatid cyst caused by the tapeworm Echinococcus granulosus.
  • At CE4 stage, the cyst has a solid appearance with multiple daughter cysts resembling a "bag of wool" on imaging.
  • The 'bag of wool' appearance indicates a specific stage in the progression of the hydatid cyst and is important for proper diagnosis and management of the condition.

REFERENCE: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 74

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has decreased vision, pain, redness, and photophobia in the left eye for three days. He is otherwise healthy, without known systemic disease. On examination the right eye is without inflammation. Examination of the left eye reveals 3+ anterior chamber cells and 2-3+ vitreous cells, and haze with 5 clock hours of retinitis anterior to the equator. He is HIV negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A rapid onset of symptomatic retinitis anterior to the equator in a non-immunosuppressed patient best fits the description of viral acute retinal necrosis.

Toxocara would be an unusual cause of retinal necrosis, especially in this age group.

Sarcoidosis is not the differential diagnosis, but is less likely with this picture. A bilateral granulomatous pan uveitis, not quite as rapid in its course, would be much more typical, although retinal necrosis is possible.

Toxoplasmosis is unlikely to result in such a large area of retinal necrosis unless there is immunosuppression, including corticosteroid injection.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 470

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in isovaleric acidemia?
questions.solution:
In isovaleric acidemia, ingestion of protein-rich foods elevates isovalerate, the deacylation product of isovaleryl-CoA.

The impaired enzyme in isovaleric acidemia is isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase.

Vomiting, acidosis, and comma follow ingestion of excess protein.

The urine has a characteristic cheesy or sweaty odor.

Accumulated isovaleryl-CoA is hydrolyzed to isovalerate and excreted.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated Biochemistry 30th edition, page 309-310

questions.text: The Framingham heart study to study the risk factors for cardiovascular study was a:
questions.solution:
The Framingham heart study was initiated in 1948 by the United States Public Health Service to study the relationship of a number of (risk) factors (e.g., serum cholesterol, blood pressure, weight, smoking) to the subsequent development of cardiovascular disease. The town of Framingham (Massachusetts) had a population of 28,000 in 1948. The study was planned for 20 years in view of the slow development of heart disease.

4,469 (69 per cent) of the 6,507 in the initial sample actually underwent the first examination. After the first examination, the study population was examined every 2 years for a 20 years period. Information was obtained with regard to serum cholesterol, blood pressure, weight and cigarette smoking. Although biennial examinations were the main source of follow up information, other means were also adopted to detect CHD (e.g., Death certificate records).

This model of starting with people exposed to and not exposed to a particular risk factor and following them for development of disease is typical of a cohort study.

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page 88

questions.text: Teenage pregnancy is associated with all except -
questions.solution:
Teenage pregnancy is defined as pregnancy occurring in a girl below the age of 19. It accounts for about 10-12% of all births.

  • Long-term consequences of teenage pregnancy include physical, psychological, social, and educational challenges for both the mother and the child.
  • Induced abortions may increase the risk of recurrent miscarriage and preterm labor in subsequent pregnancies.
  • Teenage pregnancy is associated with increased risks of cesarean section (a) and eclampsia (b).
  • Maternal mortality rate is higher among teenage pregnancies (d).
  • However, teenage pregnancy is not associated with post-dated pregnancy (c).

Reference: Textbook of Obstetrics, Sheila Balakrishnan 1st edition, page no 407

choices.text: Inhibition of expression of CTLA-4 on tumor-specific T cells

questions.text: Which of the following is a mechanism of immune evasion by cancer?
questions.solution:
Mechanisms of immune evasion by cancer cells -

  1. Selective outgrowth of antigen-negative variants
  2. Loss/reduced expression of MHC molecules, thereby losing the ability to display cytosolic antigens and escaping attack by cytotoxic T cells
  3. Engagement of pathways that inhibit T-cell activation. Tumor cells may promote the expression of the inhibitory receptor CTLA-4 on tumor-specific T cells, which binds to and removes its ligands, the B7 molecules, from APCs, thus reducing the engagement of the activating costimulatory receptor CD28. This not only prevents sensitization but also may induce long-lived unresponsiveness in tumor specific T cells
  4. Secretion of immunosuppressive factors like TGF-β
  5. Induction of regulatory T cells (Tregs)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 311-312

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a non-opioid analgesic and also does not inhibit prostaglandin synthesis?
questions.solution:
Nefopam is a nonopioid analgesic which does not inhibit PG synthesis but relieves traumatic, postoperative and short-lasting musculoskeletal pain. It may be used if pain is persistent and is not adequately relieved by other analgesics.

Nefopam produces anticholinergic (dry mouth, urinary retention, blurred vision) and sympathomimetic (tachycardia, nervousness) side effects, and nausea is often dose limiting. It is contraindicated in epileptics.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no 224

questions.text: A 40 years old patient presented to the emergency with diarrhea and fever for the last 4 days. On examination of his stool sample in the lab, it was found that it has blood and pus cells. The organism causing this disease is classified on the basis of fermentation of which of the following sugars?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is dysentery, caused by Shigella.

Classification of shigella - Fermentation of mannitol is of importance in classification

  1. Mannitol fermentation done by -
    1. flexneri
    2. boydii
    3. sonnei
  2. Mannitol not fermented by -
    1. S. dysenteriae
