questions.text: For early total care after trauma, the venous lactate level should be
questions.solution:
• For early total care after trauma, the venous lactate level should be < 2 mmol/L (a).
  • Monitoring venous lactate levels is an important part of early management in trauma patients.
  • A lactate level of < 2 mmol/L indicates that the patient's tissue perfusion and oxygenation are adequate.
  • Higher lactate levels may indicate inadequate tissue oxygenation and perfusion, which could be a sign of shock or hypoperfusion and requires immediate attention and intervention.

Venous lactate is an essential marker of resuscitation

  • <2 mmol/L - ETC
  • 2-3 mmol/L - look at the trend (increasing or decreasing)
  • >3 mmol/L - may be under-resuscitated; should either have further resuscitation or DCS if surgery is urgent
  • >5 mmol/L - DCS

REFERENCE: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 359

questions.text: Corneal Curvature is best measured by
questions.solution:
Important Investigations Related to Cornea -

  1. Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness
  2. Keratometry: To measure the corneal curvature
  3. Corneal topography: Measures corneal curvature, shape and thickness
  4. Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium.
  5. Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography (AS-OCT): To assess different corneal layers
  6. Vital stains:
    1. Fluorescein stain: To identify epithelial defect
    2. Rose Bengal stain: It stains the degenerated epithelial cells. It causes severe stinging, hence rarely used.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 249

questions.text: Symptomatic neonatal CNS involvement is most commonly seen in which group of congenital intrauterine infections?
questions.solution:
CNS manifestations are present in all TORCH infections. They develop these symptoms in late infancy and not in neonatal age.

Herpes and Rubella infections have more chances of having CNS manifestations in the neonatal period compared to other TORCH infections.

Reference: Cloherty and Stark's manual of newborn care, SA ed., page no 663

questions.text: A woman comes to your OPD with a history of domestic violence. She alleged that she was hit by a frying pan on her head 2 days back. What would you expect the color of the bruise to be?
questions.solution:
Age of Bruise

A bruise heals by destruction and removal of the extravasated blood. The more vascular the area, the smaller the contusion, and the healthier the individual, the more rapid the healing. The red cells disintegrate by haemolysis, and the hemoglobin is broken down into hemosiderin, haematoidin and bilirubin by the action of enzymes.

Factors affecting color of contusion include

  1. depth of bleeding
  2. amount of bleeding
  3. environmental lighting
  4. overlying skin color.
  5. The color change starts at the periphery and extends inwards to the center.
  6. At first: Red
  7. Few hours to 3 days: Blue
  8. 4th day: Bluish-black to brown (hemosiderin)
  9. 5 to 6 days: Greenish (hematoidin)
  10. 7 to 12 days: Yellow (bilirubin)
  11. 2 weeks: Normal


Subconjunctival ecchymoses do not undergo usual color changes due to diffusion of atmospheric oxygen through the conjunctival tissue. They are at first bright red, then yellow before disappearing.

References: The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, page no 185

questions.text: Which of the following does not have cholesterol?
questions.solution:
Cholesterol is present in tissues and in plasma either as free cholesterol or combined with a long-chain fatty acid as cholesteryl ester, the storage form. In plasma, both forms are transported in lipoproteins.

Cholesterol is an amphipathic lipid and as such is an essential structural component of membranes, where it is important for the maintenance of the correct permeability and fluidity, and of the outer layer of plasma lipoproteins. It is synthesized in many tissues from acetyl-CoA and is the precursor of all other steroids in the body, including corticosteroids, sex hormones, bile acids, and vitamin D.

Specialized Products of Cholesterol -

  1. Bile Acids [Excretory form of Cholesterol]
  2. Vitamin D
  3. Sex Hormones
  4. Corticosteroids

Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 30th edition, page 267

choices.text: Proportion of infants who are fully immunized
Percentage of pregnant women who receive antenatal care

questions.text: Which among the following is not a healthcare utilization indicator:

choices.text: It is inherited as autosomal dominant
Abnormality occurs in collagen type III

questions.text: What is not true regarding the vascular type of Ehlers Danlos syndrome?
questions.solution:
EDS result from some mutations in genes that encode collagen, enzymes that modify collagen, and less commonly other proteins present in the extracellular matrix.

Option B:

AD inheritance - Type I, II, III, IV, VIIa, VIIb

AR inheritance - Type VI, VIIc

Option C: Vascular EDS results from abnormalities of type III collagen. In two forms of EDS—arthrochalasia type and dermatosparaxis type-the fundamental defect is in the conversion of type I procollagen to collagen. In Classic type EDS, mutations in the genes for type V collagen (COL5A1 and COL5A2) have been detected.

Option D: Clinical features of EDS may include fragile, hyperextensible skin vulnerable to trauma; hypermobile joints; and ruptures involving the colon, cornea, or large arteries. Wound healing is poor.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate dose of aminophylline to be given as slow i.v. infusion in children for bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Aminophylline

It is water soluble, can be injected i.v. but not i.m. or s.c.-highly irritating.

250-500 mg oral or slow i.v. injection; children 7.5 mg/kg i.v.;

Intravenous aminophylline, an ethylene diamine ester of theophylline that is water soluble, has been used for many years in the treatment of acute severe asthma.

The recommended dose is 6 mg/kg given intravenously over 20-30 min, followed by a maintenance dose of 0.5 mg/kg/hr.

questions.text: A 45 years old patient was admitted to the hospital with persistent cough that produces thick mucus, wheezing, exercise intolerance, repeated lung infections and inflamed nasal passages, fluffy nose and recurrent sinusitis. The clinician suspected cystic fibrosis. The most common organism associated with these symptoms in a patient of CF is
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas is non capsulated but many strains have a mucoid slime layer. Mucoid strains, particularly isolated from cystic fibrosis patients, have an abundance of extracellular matrix polysaccharide composed of alginate polymers

This forms a loose capsule (Glycocalyx) in which microcolonies of the bacillus are enmeshed and protected host defence.

Non mucoid Pseudomonas causes many infections ranging from skin, pneumonia, UTI etc., but is not involved in cystic fibrosis

choices.text: Topical corticosteroids are useful in the treatment of early Fuchs' dystrophy

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes Fuchs' dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Symptoms of Fuchs' dystrophy may include decreased vision from stromal and epithelial edema, as well as pain from epithelial breakdown in more advanced stages of the disease.

Corticosteroids have no beneficial effect in the early stages of this dystrophic, noninflammatory disorder. Although lowering the intraocular pressure in the patient with an edematous cornea from Fuchs' dystrophy may temporarily help the edema, elevated intraocular pressure is not a consistent feature of the disorder. Specular microscopy early in the disease demonstrates pleomorphism, polymegathism, and a disruption of the endothelial monolayer by Descemet's membrane excrescences. Vesicular endothelial changes are seen more characteristically in posterior polymorphous dystrophy.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 259

questions.text: A 3-day-old vaginally delivered neonate presents with fever and cough after. On examination, she has coarse breath sounds and labs show an increased WBC count. Chest X-ray is clearly consistent with pneumonia. Which of the following organisms are more likely to be associated?
questions.solution:
Most early-onset pneumonia (generally within three days of birth) is caused by aerobic bacteria, although anaerobes such as Bacteroides sp. occasionally are recovered.

Group B streptococcus (GBS) causes most early-onset pneumonia.

Other less common bacterial pathogens include Listeria monocytogenes and Mycobacterium tuberculosis, both of which can be transmitted transplacentally.

Although transplacental infection by M. tuberculosis often results in primary liver involvement, pneumonia may be the sole manifestation or may accompany hepatic disease. Tuberculosis occurs with greater frequency in HIV-infected patients.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., page no 2091

questions.text: Secondary ossification centers generally ossify after birth, but a few of them develop in the last few weeks of intrauterine life. These include all except the following:
questions.solution:
Secondary ossification center of the Distal Femur develops prior to birth, not proximal femur.

Secondary ossification centers that appear before birth include the following:

  1. Cuboid
  2. Calcaneum
  3. Talus
  4. Distal Femur
  5. Proximal Tibia

Head of Humerus

Visualization of these are considered proof of a full term birth.

References: The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, page no 76-80

choices.text: Represents primarily cholesterol that is being removed from peripheral cells
Binds to a receptor and cholesterol diffuses across the cell membrane
On accumulation in the cell inhibits replenishment of LDL receptors
When enters a cell, suppresses activity of acyl- CoA: cholesterol acyltransferase ACAT

questions.text: What is true about the cholesterol present in LDL?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of uptake of LDL by LDL receptor -

LDL receptors occur on the cell surface in pits that are coated on the cytosolic side of the cell membrane with a protein called clathrin. The LDL receptor spans the membrane, the B-100 binding region being at the exposed amino terminal end. After binding, LDL is taken up intact by endocytosis. The Apo protein and cholesteryl ester are then hydrolyzed in the lysosomes, and cholesterol is translocated into the cell.

The receptors are recycled to the cell surface.

LDL is taken up intact, and cholesterol alone diffuses across the membrane.

Cholesterol balance in tissues -

This influx of cholesterol inhibits the transcription of the genes encoding

HMG-CoA synthase, HMG-CoA reductase, and other enzymes involved in cholesterol synthesis

The LDL receptor itself, via the SREBP pathway, thus coordinates cholesterol synthesis and uptake.

In addition, ACAT activity is stimulated, promoting cholesterol esterification.

Option a: LDL cholesterol is primarily from other lipoproteins whereas HDL cholesterol is from peripheral organs.

Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 30th edition , page 271

questions.text: The logo given is for which of the following healthcare program?
questions.solution:
• The logo provided represents the India Newborn Action Plan (INAP).
  • INAP is a healthcare program in India aimed at improving newborn health and reducing neonatal mortality.
  • It focuses on various interventions and strategies for newborn care, including facility-based care (FBNC) and home-based care (HBNC).
  • INAP works towards ensuring comprehensive and quality healthcare for newborns through Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK) or the Newborn Child Safety Program.

questions.text: A patient with discharge per vagina was evaluated and on endocervical biopsy Chlamydia was found. Treatment to be given in this case is:
questions.solution:
Management of Chlamydia

Uncomplicated chlamydia can be treated with Tetracycline (500 mg 4 times daily), Doxycycline (1000 mg twice daily), Erythromycin (500 mg 4 times daily), Fluoroquinolone -ofloxacin 300 mg twice daily, or Azithromycin -single dose - 1 g

Advantages of Azithromycin are:

  1. Single dose regimen - 1 g stat dose (It is as effective as 7 days of doxycycline treatment).
  2. Better patient compliance
  3. Fewer gastrointestinal side effects.

Disadvantages

High cost of azithromycin.

Contact tracing

Patients with asymptomatic infection and their sex partners form a major burden of chlamydial infection so, contact tracing should always be done (wherever possible).

Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 1st edition, Page no. 66

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is seen in septic shock?
questions.solution:
Septic patients exhibit insulin resistance and hyperglycemia.

Option B: Cytokines such as TNF and IL-1, stress-induced hormones (such as glucagon, growth hormone, and glucocorticoids), and catecholamines all drive gluconeogenesis.

Option C: The pro-inflammatory cytokines suppress insulin release while simultaneously promoting insulin resistance in the liver and other tissues, likely by impairing the surface expression of glucose transporter-4 (GLUT-4).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 137

questions.text: A 68 years old male patient presented with resting tremor, rigidity and bradykinesia. It was diagnosed to be a case of Parkinsonism. Which of the following therapy is least useful in this case?
questions.solution:
Parkinson's disease -

It is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by tremors, rigidity and bradykinesia. Later on, behavioral abnormalities and dementia also occur.

The principle of treatment is to increase dopamine levels in the brain. The drugs used are -

  1. Levodopa
  2. Peripheral decarboxylase inhibitors (carbidopa)
  3. MAO-B inhibitors (selegiline)
  4. Dopamine agonists (pramipexole, ropinirole)
  5. Others - amantadine, anticholinergics, istradefylline

Rivastigmine is a cerebral selective anticholinergic.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no 122, 453

choices.text: Commonest cause of middle ear infection
Respiratory tract of carrier is most important source of infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pneumococcus is false?
questions.solution:
Meningitis is the most serious pneumococcal infection.

The most important virulence factor of pneumococci is capsular polysaccharide.

Pneumococci is the most common cause of otitis media.

The source of human infection is the respiratory tract of carriers and less often, of patients. Pneumococci occur in the throat of approximately half of the population sampled at any time

choices.text: Events that led to the injury

questions.text: All of the following are parts of the AMPLE' history except
questions.solution:
Following the history of the presenting complaint, it is important to collect information beyond that of the injury. The AMPLE mnemonic is an abbreviated system taught in ATLS that is designed to provide key information quickly in a focused way.

  1. A: Allergies
  2. M: Medication - important to ask about anticoagulant and antiplatelet therapies, corticosteroid use and any possible immunosuppressive treatment
  3. P: Past medical and surgical history - has the patient had an anesthetic in the past and were there any complications
  4. L: Last time - something to eat or drink
  5. E: Events - events that led to the injury

In the multiply injured patient or patients with altered levels of consciousness, gain as much collateral history as possible. Listen to the account of prehospital personnel; for example, the amount of cabin intrusion in a vehicle or whether a collision was head-on or side-on.

REFERENCE: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 416

questions.text: Stage 2 in POP-Q classification is when points A and B are at
questions.solution:
New Classification of Prolapse-POP-Q Classification

More recent grading system of prolapse considers the individual pelvic organ and its distance in relation to the hymen.

Pelvic Organ Prolapse (POP) Qualification identifies several points (total 9) within and around the vagina and measures the distance of each point from the hymen while the patient performs valsalva.

The points which lie inside the vagina are reported as negative numbers and those that lie outside as positive numbers. Staging is done according to the measurement.



The perineal body is normally at the level of ischial tuberosity. Descent of >2 cm below this level with flattening of the intergluteal sulcus indicates perineal descent.

choices.text: Reticulocyte production index (RPI) is more than 2
M:E ratio decreased in bone marrow
Zinc protoporphyrin can detect iron deficiency before anemia develops

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the laboratory findings in a patient of iron deficiency anemia (IDA)?
questions.solution:
In IDA, both the relative and absolute number of reticulocytes can be normal or even slightly increased, but the reticulocyte count is decreased relative to the severity of the anemia with a reticulocyte production index (RPI) of less than 2.

Option A: The blood film demonstrates progressive poikilocytosis. The most frequent poikilocytes are target cells (codocytes), elliptocytes, and dacryocytes (tear drop cells).

Option C: The bone marrow shows mild to moderate erythroid hyperplasia with a decreased M:E ratio.

Option D: The ZPP measurement correlates inversely with serum ferritin concentration and is more cost effective. It can detect iron depletion before anemia develops and thus is a good screening tool for the early stages of iron deficiency.

Reference: Clinical laboratory hematology by Shirlyn McKenzie, 4th edition, Page no 243-244

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetic agents is painless on intravenous administration?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is a strong analgesic drug and is water soluble. Its injection is not painful.

Propofol and etomidate solutions have to be made in oil due to poor water solubility, so these injections are quite painful.

Methohexitone can cause hyperalgesia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common primary blast injury?
questions.solution:
Tympanic membrane (TM) rupture is the most common primary blast injury. Patients may be asymptomatic or have a degree of transient hearing loss and otorrhoea. Previously, the presence of TM rupture was used as a marker for other occult blast injuries.

questions.text: Gautam and Rani are a married couple who have 2 children, 30 years old Mahesh and 25 years old Suresh. Mahesh weds Gopika and move abroad to settle in the United States, while Suresh stays with his parents as he is still studying, Which stage of the family cycle is this family in?
questions.solution:
• The family stage that Gautam and Rani's family is in Contraction
  • Contraction stage occurs when the family size decreases due to children leaving the household for various reasons such as education, work, or marriage.
  • In this case, Mahesh getting married and moving abroad represents the contraction stage as the family size reduces with one child leaving the household.
  • Suresh staying with his parents for education signifies that the family is still in the contraction stage, and the family roles and dynamics are adjusting to the changes.

Reference: Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page 739

questions.text: A 10-yr old child presented with complaints of abdominal pain and lethargy, and shortness of breath after exertion for a long time. Parents have had consanguineous marriage. On examination, pallor was observed. Splenomegaly was also noted. Laboratory reports showed pancytopenia with markedly reduced Hb. His peripheral smear showed giant erythroblastosis (approximately 50 mcM), containing up to 16 nuclei. Agglutination by anti-i antibodies was also observed. Identify the type of congenital dyserythropoietic anemia.
questions.solution:
CDA III is morphologically distinct from Types I and II because of the presence of giant erythroblasts (up to 50 mcM) containing up to 16 nuclei. Sometimes the erythrocytes are agglutinated by anti-I and anti-i antibodies.

Option A: CDA I

Bone marrow erythroblasts are megaloblastic and often binucleate with incomplete division of nuclear segments. The incomplete nuclear division is characterized by internuclear chromatin bridges.

Option B: CDA II

Bone marrow precursors are not megaloblastic but are typically multinucleated with up to seven nuclei.

Reference: Clinical laboratory hematology by Shirlyn McKenzie, 4th edition, Pg 339

questions.text: Which of the following antipsychotic drugs is available as a depot injection?
questions.solution:
The common problem of medication non-adherence among schizophrenia patients has led to the development of long-acting injectable (LAI) antipsychotic medications, often referred to as depot antipsychotics.

There are currently four available LAI forms

  1. Fluphenazine decanoate
  2. Haloperidol decanoate

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has negligible chances to worsen myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:

    3. Quinolones

questions.text: Presence of HBeAg in patients with hepatitis is a marker of
questions.solution:
Hepatitis B virus infection incubation period varies from 30 days to 180 days.

Various antigen and antibodies are detected to see whether it is acute or chronic.

HBsAg - if positive for 6 months - it is called carrier stage

HBeAg - if present it suggest high infectivity

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 9th edition, Page no 590

questions.text: Which classification is used for fasciocutaneous flaps?
questions.solution:
Fasciocutaneous flaps comprise a fascial component that augments the fap blood supply owing to a network of subfascial, fascial and suprafascial vessels. Fasciocutaneous flaps may be classified according to Cormack and Lamberty

  1. Type A: multiple perforators that can be direct or indirect (e.g., Ponten flap)
  2. Type B: single perforator that is usually direct and runs along the axis of the flap (e.g., the scapular or parascapular flaps)
  3. Type C: segmental perforators that arise from the same source vessel (e.g., the radial forearm and lateral arm flaps)
  4. Type D: similar to type C; however, the flap is raised as an osteo myo fasciocutaneous flap (e.g., the free fibula flap)

Mathes and Nahai classification is used for muscle flaps.

REFERENCE: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 696

questions.text: The commonest cause of nonengagement at term, in primigravida women is
questions.solution:
Engagement is said to occur when the greatest transverse diameter of the presenting part, has passed through the pelvic inlet. In all cephalic presentations, the greatest transverse diameter is always the biparietal.

Engagement occurs in multipara with commencement of labor in the late 1st stage after rupture of membranes and in nullipara during the last few weeks of pregnancy, i.e. 38 weeks

In primigravida the most common cause of non-engagement at term is deflexed head or occipito-posterior position followed by cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD)

Since deflexed head or occipito-posterior is not given in the option, CPD is the answer.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, Page no:81, 82, 352

Option B: It was previously known as pure erythroid leukemia.

questions.text: All of the following are complications of endoscopic third ventriculostomy except
questions.solution:
Endoscopic third ventriculostomy

  1. This procedure is especially useful in obstructive hydrocephalus due to aqueduct stenosis.
  2. A neuro endoscope is inserted into the frontal horn of the lateral ventricle and then into the third ventricle via the foramen of Monro.
  3. The floor of the ventricle is then opened between the mamillary bodies and the pituitary recess. Free drainage between the third ventricle and the adjacent subarachnoid cisterns is then possible, without the infection risk posed by implanted tubing.
  4. Re blockage of this route is common, however, and many patients will subse- quently require a shunt.
  5. Rare but serious complications include damage to the basilar artery or forniceal damage, resulting in permanent memory impairment.

REFERENCE: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no: 706

choices.text: Women of child-bearing age (15- 34 or 39 years of age)
All children at one year of age

questions.text: Ideally, which of the following groups of individuals receives highest priority in a vaccination program for rubella?
questions.solution:
In the light of the experience gained during the past years, the immunization strategies to prevent congenital rubella infection have been modified - the priorities being first to protect women of child-bearing age (15- 34 or 39 years of age) and then to interrupt transmission of rubella by vaccinating all children currently aged 1-14 years, and subsequently all children at one year of age. The program would then revert to one of routine universal immunization of all children at age 1 (preferably using combined measles-rubella or the measles-mumps-rubella vaccines).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, pg164

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for induction of labor?

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be used to diagnose PNH?
questions.solution:
It is recommended that at least two different antibodies be used for a diagnosis of PNH (CD55, CD59, CD14).

The Ham (acidified-serum lysis)test is a more specific test for PNH cells.

The fluorescent-labeled inactive toxin aerolysin (FLAER) test is another method used to diagnose PNH. This technique utilizes toxin from the bacterium Aeromonas hydrophila bound to a fluorochrome. The toxin binds directly to the GPI anchor itself, not to an attached protein, which makes it a direct measurement of GPI-deficient cells.

Reference: Clinical laboratory hematology by Shirlyn McKenzie, 4th edition, Pg 378-379

choices.text: It can be given in pregnancy
It is contraindicated in diabetes mellitus

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding the use of aliskiren?
questions.solution:
Aliskiren

Direct renin inhibitors (DRIs) are the latest class of RAS inhibitory drugs, of which only one member Aliskiren has become available for the treatment of cardiovascular and renal diseases in which ACE inhibitors and ARBs are currently used.

Aliskiren is a nonpeptide which binds selectively to the catalytic site of renin and competitively blocks the access of angiotensinogen to this site. As a result, Ang I is not produced and the effector chain of RAS is interrupted. While the concentration of renin in plasma is increased by feedback, the plasma renin activity (PRA) is decreased.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no 538

questions.solution:

choices.text: Parathyroid carcinoma is a rare malignancy occurring in approximately 1% of cases of PHPT.
History of previous neck irradiation is the only known environmental risk factor
It is difficult to diagnose preoperatively as it biochemically resembles PHPT
All parafibromin positive and PGP 9.5 negative tumors should be considered for genetic screening

questions.text: All of the following are true about parathyroid carcinoma except -
questions.solution:
Parathyroid carcinoma is a rare malignancy occurring in approximately 1% of cases of PHPT, with an estimated prevalence of 0.005% of all cancers. While the etiology remains unclear, recent advances in molecular biology suggest that there may be an underlying genetic basis. Currently, a history of previous neck irradiation remains the only known environmental risk factor. However, given that it can arise in patients with end-stage renal disease as well as in those with MEN type 1, malignant transformation in hyperplastic glands may also occur.

Immunohistochemical evidence of downregulation of parafibromin has a sensitivity of 67% and a specificity of 100% for detecting parathyroid carcinoma. Parafibromin immunohistochemistry may be used with immunohistochemistry for (protein gene product) PGP 9.5. This is a protein encoded by ubiquitin carboxyl-terminal esterase LI. It is upregulated in parathyroid carcinoma and has a sensitivity of 78% and a specificity of 100%.

All parafibromin-negative and PGP 9.5-positive tumors should be considered for genetic screening.

REFERENCE: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 886

choices.text: No Free flow of population movements

questions.text: In which of the following population characteristics, Hardy-Weinberg law can't be applied?
questions.solution:
Prerequisites for applying the Hardy-Weinberg law to a population -

  1. There should be random mating (no selective mating permitted)
  2. There should not be any natural selection
  3. No mutations/changes in DNA sequence
  4. There should not be Free flow of population movements
  5. Population size should be large

choices.text: Regular uterine contraction without cervical changes
Length of cervix < 2.5 cm on TVS

questions.text: Diagnostic criteria for preterm labor include all of the following except -
questions.solution:
DIAGNOSIS OF PRETERM LABOR -

  1. Regular uterine contractions with or without pain (at least one in every 10 minutes)
  2. Dilatation (> 2 cm) and effacement (80%) of the cervix
  3. Length of the cervix (measured by TVS) < 2.5 cm and funneling of the internal os and
  4. Pelvic pressure, backache and/or vaginal discharge or bleeding.

Reference: DC Dutta's textbook of obstetrics 8th edition, page no 366

questions.text: Which of the following is not a principal mediator involved in chemotaxis, leukocyte recruitment and activation?
questions.solution:
Mediators involved in chemotaxis, leukocyte recruitment and activation are

  • TNF
  • IL-1
  • Chemokines
  • C3a and C5a

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 92

choices.text: Its growth is inhibited by griseofulvin
Candida shows mycelia and chlamydospores on corn meal agar
Candida is not present in normal feces

questions.text: True about Candida albicans is-
questions.solution:
Candida albicans

It is the most common cause of mucosal candidiasis

All candida species pathogenic for humans are also encountered as commensals of humans, particularly in the mouth, steel and vagina.

They grow rapidly on simple media as oval budding cells at 25 to 37°C. Both yeasts and pseudohyphae are present.

Candida albicans is differentiated from other candida species by -

  1. It forms true hyphae (mycelia) or germ tubes when grown in serum.
  2. It forms thick walled large spores called chlamydospores when grown in corn meal agar
  3. It is dimorphic

Ref - Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 607

questions.text: The modified Weiss histopathological system is used for -
questions.solution:
Adrenocortical carcinoma

  1. Tumors are often large (>10 cm) with a cut surface that ranges from orange to brown. Necrosis is usually present.
  2. Distinguishing between benign and malignant adrenocortical tumors may be difficult, with the presence of local invasion or distant metastasis being the only definitive criteria. If neither are present, the modified Weiss histopathological system may be used to guide management.
  3. It comprises five criteria
    1. >6 mitoses/50 high-power fields
    2. ≤25% clear tumor cells in the cytoplasm
    3. abnormal mitoses
    4. necrosis
    5. capsular invasion
  4. If a criterion is absent, it is scored 0; if present, it scores 2 for the first two criteria and 1 each for the last three. A total score ≥3 is suggestive of malignant behavior.

More recently the use of the Ki-67 proliferation index has been advocated, with increasing counts suggesting poorer prognosis.

REFERENCE: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 895

choices.text: ILRs are to maintain a cabinet temperature between +2°C to + 8°C and are used to store vaccines at district and sub-district level
These types of refrigerators are top opening because they can hold the cold air inside better than a refrigerator with a front opening
It can keep vaccine safe with minimum 10 hours continuous electricity supply in a 24-hour period
Vaccines like OPV. BCG, measles, and JE can be kept at the bottom of the basket while DPT. TT, hep B, IPV and pentavalent vaccines and diluents are kept in upper part

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about an ice lined refrigerator (ILR)?
questions.solution:
• An ice-lined refrigerator (ILR) is used to store vaccines at district and sub-district levels, maintaining temperatures between +2°C to +8°C.
  • ILRs are top-opening refrigerators, which help retain cold air better than front-opening ones.
  • They can keep vaccines safe for a minimum of 8 hours with continuous electricity supply in a 24-hour period.
  • Vaccines like OPV, BCG, measles, and JE are kept at the bottom of the basket, while DPT, TT, hep B, IPV, pentavalent vaccines, and diluents are stored in the upper part of the ILR.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page 118

questions.text: A 30 years old G2P1 previous preterm delivery comes for antenatal visit at 20 weeks of gestation. She denies having any abdominal pain or vaginal discharge. Her TVS done at 19 weeks of gestation reveals cervical length 2 cm and funneling of internal os. On per speculum examination herniation of membranes is seen from the os. What would be the best management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
CERVICAL INCOMPETENCE:

Diagnosis:

  1. Clinical: history of repeated mid trimester painless cervical dilatation
  2. Sonography: Short cervix < 25 mm; Funneling of the internal os> 1 cm.

Speculum examination: Detection of dilatation of internal os with herniation of the membranes

Management - Cerclage operation

Reference: DC Dutta's textbook of obstetrics 8th edition, Page no 220

questions.text: Following is the image of peripheral smear of an 18-yr old G6PD-deficient patient, who recently suffered from typhoid fever. Identify the inclusions shown in the inset, stained with supravital stain.
questions.solution:
Red cells with precipitates of denatured globin (Heinz bodies) revealed by supravital staining. As the splenic macrophages pluck out these inclusions, 'bite cells' like the one in this smear are produced.

Many infections can trigger hemolysis in G6PD deficient patients; viral hepatitis, pneumonia, and typhoid fever are among those most likely to do so.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 640-641

questions.text: Which of the following structures is formed by the obliterated fetal umbilical arteries?
questions.solution:
Median umbilical ligament (single) is formed by the urachus, a fibrous fetal remnant that extends from the bladder apex to the umbilicus. Clinically, this ligament may be seen at laparotomy during peritoneal incision as a white, midline, fibrous cord.

Medial umbilical ligaments (paired) are formed by the obliterated fetal umbilical arteries.

Lateral umbilical ligaments (paired) contain the patent inferior epigastric vessels.

Ref.- William's obstetrics 26th edition, Page no 119

questions.text: As per the syndromic management of lower abdominal pain in females, follow up after treatment needed at what time?
questions.solution:
Syndromic management of Lower Abdominal Pain In female

  1. Treatment: KIT 6 yellowcolored
  2. In mild or moderate PID (in the absence of tubo ovarian abscess), outpatient treatment can be given. Therapy is required to cover Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis and anaerobes.
    1. Cefixime 400 mg orally twice daily for 7 days + Tab. Metronidazole 400 mg orally, twice daily for 14 days. + Doxycycline, 100 mg orally, twice a day for 2 weeks (to treat chlamydial infection)
    2. Additionally, Tab. Ibuprofen 400 mg orally, three times a day for 3-5 days.
    3. Ranitidine 150 mg orally, twice daily to prevent gastritis.
  3. Remove intrauterine device, if present, under antibiotic cover of 24-48 hours.
  4. Advise abstinence during the course of treatment and educate on correct and consistent use of condoms.
  5. Observe for 3 days. If no improvement (i.e., absence of fever, reduction in abdominal tenderness, reduction in cervical movement, adnexal and uterine tenderness) or if symptoms worsen, refer for inpatient treatment.

Follow up- Schedule return visit after 3 days, 7 days and 14 days to ensure compliance.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page 379

questions.text: All are done in management of shoulder dystocia except:
questions.solution:
Shoulder Dystocia:

The term shoulder dystocia is used to define a wide range of difficulties encountered in the delivery of the shoulders (A head to body delivery time exceeding 60 secs defines shoulder dystocia).

  • First-line measures include calling for extra help, discouraging maternal pushing, providing a liberal episiotomy, and avoiding fundal pressure.
  • The McRoberts maneuver is the first-line intervention, involving flexion and abduction of the maternal hips.
  • Second-line measures include the Wood's maneuver, which rotates the posterior shoulder to release the impacted anterior shoulder.
  • Third-line measures, if needed, involve more invasive procedures like cleidotomy, symphysiotomy, or the Zavanellimaneuver followed by cesarean section.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, Page no: 406

choices.text: False negative tuberculin test is seen in sarcoidosis
False positive tuberculin test is seen in atypical mycobacterial infection
False positive interferon gamma release test is common in immunosuppressive patients

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding testing for latent tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
False-positive results are uncommon with Interferon-γ release assays (IGRAs).

Option A: False-negative reactions may occur in the setting of certain viral infections, sarcoidosis, malnutrition, Hodgkin lymphoma, immunosuppression, and (notably) active tuberculous disease.

Option B: A false-positive tuberculin skin test may result from infection by atypical mycobacteria or prior vaccination with BCG.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 371

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensives causes sedation as an adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of clonidine -

  1. Sedation, mental depression, disturbed sleep; dryness of mouth, nose and eyes (secretion is decreased by central action), constipation (antisecretory effect on the intestines).
  2. Impotence, salt and water retention, bradycardia.
  3. Postural hypotension occurs, but is mostly asymptomatic.
  4. Alarming rise in BP, in excess of pretreatment level, with tachycardia, restlessness, anxiety, sweating, headache, nausea and vomiting occur in some patients when doses of clonidine are missed for 1-2 days.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no 611

questions.text: Cryptococcus is least likely to cause infection of -
questions.solution:
Cryptococcosis

Acquired by inhalation of the fungus into the lungs. Rarely acquired through skin or mucosa.

Pulmonary infection has a tendency toward spontaneous resolution and is frequently asymptomatic.

Silent hematogenous spread to the brain occurs, especially in basal ganglia or the head of the caudate nucleus.

Clinical features -

  1. Self limiting pulmonary infection→ Most common form of cryptococcosis (Green wood)
  2. Meningoencephalitis (most patients have at the time of diagnosis)
  3. Pulmonary symptoms
  4. Skin lesions (10%)
  5. Osteolytic lesions in bone (4%)
  1. Cryptococcosis in AIDS patients has less signs and symptoms
  2. Focal lesions called cryptococcomas are more common in previously normal patients
  3. Self-limiting pulmonary infection is the most common form of cryptococcosis, but most patients present with meningoencephalitis
  4. Headache is the most common symptom.

Cryptococcal lung lesions do not calcify.
Ref - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 1649, 1650

questions.text: WDHA syndrome is seen in -
questions.solution:
WDHA (watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria) syndrome is an unusual paraneoplastic condition caused by excess vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) secreted by certain tumors, primarily pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (VIPoma).

The onset of the syndrome is insidious, and diagnosis is usually delayed by months to years.

Morbidity and mortality from untreated WDHA syndrome are related to long-standing dehydration and electrolyte and acid-base disturbances resulting in chronic renal failure.

Diagnosis requires documentation of large volumes of secretory diarrhea, elevated serum VIP levels, and localization of the VIP-secreting tumor.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 917

questions.text: Which method of contraception is also known as the Billings method?
questions.solution:
The cervical mucus method is also known as the Billings method or the "ovulation method". This method is based on the observation of changes in the characteristics of cervical mucus. At the time of ovulation, cervical mucus becomes watery clear resembling raw egg white, smooth, slippery and profuse. After ovulation, under the influence of progesterone, the mucus thickens and lessens in quantity.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page 559

questions.text: Causes of intrauterine fetal death include -
questions.solution:
• Intrauterine fetal death refers to the death of the fetus before delivery, and it can be caused by various factors.
  • Diabetes (a), both pre-existing diabetes and gestational diabetes, can be a cause of intrauterine fetal death.
  • Multifetal pregnancy (b), where a woman carries multiple fetuses (twins, triplets, etc.), is also a risk factor for intrauterine fetal death.
  • Advanced maternal age (c), typically considered as age above 35 years, is associated with a higher risk of intrauterine fetal death.
  • Therefore, all of the above factors (a, b, c) are potential causes of intrauterine fetal death (d).

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 375-379

questions.text: A 15-yr old boy complains of dyspnea. Wheezing is also observed. On examination of his sputum, Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals are seen. These Charcot-Leyden crystals are formed by -
questions.solution:
Galectin-10 (GAL10), is released from eosinophils and forms crystals known as Charcot-Leyden crystals. Long recognized as a feature of asthma, recent studies have shown that these crystals are strong inducers of inflammation and mucus production.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 684

questions.text: Topical application of 400 mcg/ml mitomycin C is used for which of the given below condition
questions.solution:
Mitomycin is an anti-tumor antibiotic with alkylating agent-like properties.

It is used in superficial cancers of the urinary bladder and for squamous cell carcinoma of anus.

The drug has radiomimetic effects, and also sensitizes hypoxic tumor cells to the effects of hypoxia.

Application of topical mitomycin C after endoscopic dilation of laryngotracheal stenosis reduces the rate of restenosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no 927

questions.text: Which of the following organisms shows regressive metamorphosis?
questions.solution:
Law of migrationofcestodes

This law states that a cestode has to complete its life cycle with alternation of generation along with alteration of hosts -

Adult form in definitive host -Produce eggs-Larval form develops in intermediate host-Larval form reaches the definitive host to complete life cycle

Granulosus

  1. granulosus exists in two forms, adult and larval.
  2. The adult worm resides in the small intestine of the definitive host (dog). Adult worms release eggs in the feces.
  3. These eggs are ingested by an intermediate host (sheep, goat, man) and embryos hatch out in the intestine to reach the liver to form larval form (Hydatid cyst).

This larval form (hydatid cyst) infects the definitive host (dogs) once again when dogs consume such infective tissue of sheep. In dogs the scolices (protoscoleces) are released from the hydatid cyst and develop into adult worms.

Regressive metamorphosis

Sometimes, the hydatid cyst (containing proscolices) may rupture in the intermediate host to release its content in the tissue. If such a patient survives, the released protoscolices may revert to hydatid cyst instead of developing into an adult worm (Normally protoscoleces give rise to adult worms). This is called regressive metamorphosis because this phenomenon is against the law of migration of cestodes, because larval form (Hydatid cyst) is developing from larval form in the same host.

Reference:Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition, Page no 191, 192

choices.text: As an adjunct in pulmonary embolectomy

questions.text: All of the following are the uses of cardiopulmonary bypass except -
questions.solution:
Alternative uses of CPB :

  • Rewarming in hypothermia
  • Resuscitation in severe respiratory failure
  • As an adjunct in pulmonary embolectomy
  • Single- and double-lung transplantation
  • In cardiopulmonary trauma
  • Certain non-cardiac surgical procedures (e.g. resection of highly vascular tumours or those invading large blood vessels; e.g. the inferior vena cava in renal tumours)

Ref- Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 945

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of removal following the insertion of an IUD?
questions.solution:
WHO estimates that 15- 40 per cent of IUD removals appear to be for pain only.

The commonest complaint of women fitted with an IUD (inert or medicated), however, is increased vaginal bleeding.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page 549

questions.text: At 28 weeks gestation, amniocentesis reveals an OD 450 of 0.20 which is at the top of the third zone of the Liley's curve. The most appropriate management of such a case is:
questions.solution:
Management of Rh negative females depends on whether the female is immunized/ non immunized.

At 28 weeks intrauterine transfusion should be done.

Fresh O negative blood should be given.

In many centers-peak systolic velocity (PSV) of fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA) has replaced amniocentesis for detection of fetalanemia. The anemicfetus shunts blood preferentially to brain to maintain adequate oxygenation. The peak MCA systolic velocity increases because of increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity. If MCA peak systolic velocity is more than 1.5 MOM the fetus is likely to be anemic.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, Page no 337

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of celiac disease?
questions.solution:
The alcohol-soluble fraction of gluten, gliadin, contains most of the disease-producing components. Some gliadin peptides may induce epithelial cells to express IL-15, which in turn triggers activation and proliferation of CD8+ intraepithelial lymphocytes.

Option B & C: The histopathology of celiac disease is characterized by crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy.

Option D: Other features of fully developed celiac disease include increased numbers of plasma cells, mast cells, and eosinophils, especially within the upper part of the lamina propria.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 785

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibodies acts against IL-5?
questions.solution:
Interleukin 5 plays a pivotal role in eosinophilic inflammation and is also involved in eosinophil survival and priming.

Anti-IL-5 and anti-IL-5 receptor (IL-5Rα) antibodies inhibit eosinophilic inflammation and airway hyperresponsiveness in patients with mild asthma but has no effect on allergen challenge.

There is a significant reduction in exacerbations and sparing or oral steroids with an anti-IL-5 antibody, Mepolizumab, which has been FDA approved for use in highly selected patients with severe asthma.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page no 742

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding microsporidia?
questions.solution:
Microsporidia

  1. Microsporidia are oblique intracellular spore forming protozoa.
  2. They are gram positive.
  3. They cause disease in humans, especially as opportunistic pathogens in AIDS.
  4. Currently, eight genera of microsporidia are recognized as a cause of human disease.
    1. Encephalitozoon
    2. Trachitaleistopora
    3. Pleistophora
    4. Brachiola
    5. Nosema
    6. Enterocytozoon
    7. Vittaforma
    8. Microsporidium
  1. Encephalitozoon intestinalis can cause fever, diarrhea, sinusitis, cholangitis, bronchiolitis.
  2. Pleistophora causes myositis.
  3. Encephalitozoon hellem causes superficial keratoconjuctivitis sinusitis, respiratory tract disease and disseminated infection.
  4. Nosema and vittaforma cause stromal keratitis.
  5. Enterocytozoonbieneusi can cause chronic diarrhea and wasting.

Reference:Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 17th Edition, Page no1314

questions.text: Toe pressures are measured at the hallux. What level of absolute pressure at the hallux indicates severe ischemia?
questions.solution:
• Toe pressures are measured at the hallux (big toe).
  • Toe pressures are a non-invasive way to assess blood flow to the feet and can help diagnose peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and determine the severity of ischemia in the lower extremities.
  • A toe pressure of less than 50 mmHg suggests that there is significant obstruction in the arteries supplying blood to the toes, indicating severe ischemia and poor blood flow to the feet.


REFERENCE: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1001

questions.text: A child presented with a maculopapular rash that began behind the ears then spread to the face and rest of the body. History revealed fever, conjunctivitis and runny nose that developed a few days back. Most likely diagnosis is -
questions.solution:
1. Measles is a paramyxovirus-enveloped ssRNA virus
  2. Only source of infection is a case of measles, Carriers are not known to occur.
  3. Infective period-4 days before and 5 days after appearance of rash
  4. Infective material-secretion of nose, throat and respiratory tract
  5. Age group-6 months to 3 year
  6. C/F
    1. Prodromal stage
      • Fever, coryza with sneezing and nasal discharge, redness of eye, lacrimation, photophobia
      • A day or two before the appearance of rash, Koplik spots appear on buccal mucosa opposite the 1st and 2nd lower molars
    2. Eruptive phase-maculopapular rash which begins behind the ear and spread rapidly in a few hour over the face and neck extends down the body.
    3. Post measles stage-Weight loss, growth retardation, diarrhea

Reference: Ananthanarayan Textbook of microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 512

questions.text: A 39 year old male patient is suffering from Crohn's disease. On endoscopic examination, the colon is stenotic. Classify the patient according to the Montreal classification.
questions.solution:
• The patient with Crohn's disease, with colon stenosis on endoscopic examination, is classified according to the Montreal classification as:
  • Disease Location: A2 (b) - Involvement of the colon.
  • Disease Behaviour: B2 (b) - Stricturing behaviour, indicated by the colon stenosis.
  • Disease Phenotype: L2 (b) - Inflammatory behaviour, referring to the location of the disease in the colon.
  • Therefore, the correct classification for the patient is A2, B2, L2 (b).

REFERENCE: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1329

questions.text: A 35 years old patient developed COVID-19 pneumonia and was treated accordingly. Few months later, the patient presented with nasal congestion, sinusitis and swelling of the face. There were black lesions on the nose bridge. On CT scan diagnosis of mucormycosis was made. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B can be applied topically for oral, vaginal and cutaneous candidiasis, fungal corneal ulcer and otomycosis.

It is the most effective drug for practically all types of systemic mycoses and is the gold standard of antifungal therapy.

However, because of higher toxicity of AMB, the azole antifungals are now preferred in conditions where their efficacy approaches that of AMB.

In serious fungal infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, initial induction therapy with AMB may be replaced by the alternative safer azole antifungal drug for continuation of therapy.

Febrile neutropenia: Empirical use of i.v. AMB is often made in neutropenic patients whose fever is not responding to i.v. bactericidal antibiotics.

Leishmaniasis: AMB is the most effective drug for resistant cases of kala azar and mucocutaneous leishmaniasis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no 840

questions.text: Chronic liver failure is associated with all of the following features except -
questions.solution:
Impaired estrogen metabolism leads to hyperestrogenemia, which has several effects. It produces vascular changes that may lead to palmar erythema (a reflection of local vasodilation) and spider angiomas of the skin. In males, hyperestrogenemia may also produce hypogonadism and gynecomastia.

Option A: Persistent cholestasis can lead to pruritus (itching), the intensity of which can be profound. Some patients may scratch their skin raw, risking repeated bouts of potentially life-threatening infection. Relief may only be found in liver transplantation.

Option C: Hypogonadism can also occur in women due to disruption of hypothalamic-pituitary axis function, either through nutritional deficiencies associated with the chronic liver disease or primary hormonal alterations.

Option D: Jaundice, encephalopathy, and coagulopathy are seen in acute as well as chronic liver failure.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 828

choices.text: Peripheral neuropathy is a common adverse effect
It is active against vancomycin resistant staphylococcus aureus
Major mode of elimination is renal excretion

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tedizolid is true?
questions.solution:
1. Tedizolid is a drug similar to linezolid.
  2. Tedizolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor. It binds to the 50S ribosome and inhibits the protein synthesis.
  3. It is mainly used for gram positive organisms e.g., vancomycin resistant staphylococcus aureus (VRSA).
  4. Peripheral neuropathy and lactic acidosis are the adverse effects of tedizolid but these are not very common.
  5. Tedizolid has very good oral bioavailability (nearly 90%).
  6. It is mainly metabolized in the liver.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no 808

questions.text: A 28-yr old pregnant woman complains of anorexia, malaise and abdominal pain for 2 months. Her serum protein levels are normal. Her SGPT and SGOT are raised, while serum ALP is normal. Serology for Hepatitis A, B, C viruses is negative. On liver biopsy, extensive inflammation with numerous plasma cells and lymphocytes is noted, as shown in the image. She has also tested positive for ANA and SMA antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis -
questions.solution:
This is a case of autoimmune hepatitis.

The presentation is insidious with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, anorexia, nausea, and abdominal pain.

Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis is more common and is typically characterized by the presence of antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) and anti–smooth muscle actin (SMA) antibodies. Antibodies against soluble liver antigen/ liver-pancreas antigen (SLA/LPA) and, less commonly, anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA, more typical of primary biliary cholangitis) also may be seen.

Type 2 disease is more common in children and is characterized by anti–liver kidney microsome-1 (LKM-1) antibodies, which are directed against CYP2D6, and anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies.

On histopathology, extensive inflammation and hepatocellular injury at the interface, as well as in the hepatic parenchyma, is characteristic of autoimmune hepatitis. Numerous plasma cells in clusters are typical. Lymphocytes and plasma cells may be seen within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes, often at the interface, a curious phenomenon called emperipolesis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 839-840

questions.text: What is the energy value of human breast milk in kcal/100 mL?
questions.solution:
• The energy value of human breast milk is 70 kcals per 100 ml.
  • Breast milk is a highly nutritious and calorically dense fluid that provides essential nutrients for infants' growth and development.
  • It contains a balanced combination of proteins, fats, carbohydrates, vitamins, and minerals necessary for the baby's overall health.
  • The caloric content of breast milk is well-suited to meet the energy needs of growing infants during the early stages of life.
  • Breastfeeding is recommended as the best source of nutrition for infants up to six months of age, promoting optimal health and immunity.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page 590

questions.text: A 45-yr old woman presented with fever, weakness and bleeding gums. On laboratory work-up, her Hb was 8.2 gm/dL, TLC was 38,000/mm3 with 70% blasts, and platelet count was 15,000/mm3. On bone marrow biopsy, several cells showed bilobed nuclei and multiple Auer rods as shown in the image. Which of the following crystals are likely to be seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.solution:
Uric acid stones are common in individuals with hyperuricemia, such as patients with gout, and diseases involving rapid cell turnover, such as the leukemias.

Option A: Calcium oxalate stones are associated in about 5% of patients with hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria, such as occurs with hyperparathyroidism, diffuse bone disease, sarcoidosis, and other hypercalcemic states.

Option B: Magnesium ammonium phosphate stones are formed largely after infections by urea-splitting bacteria (e.g., Proteus and some staphylococci) that convert urea to ammonia.

Option C: Cystine stones are caused by genetic defects in the renal reabsorption of amino acids, including cystine, leading to cystinuria.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 947

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a chemical burn to the right eye. On examination, the cornea shows severe epithelial and stromal edema. The most appropriate initial management option is -
questions.solution:
Chemical burns to the eye are a medical emergency that requires immediate irrigation with normal saline to wash out the chemical and minimize ocular damage. Irrigation should continue for at least 20 mins.

Emergency treatment includes -

  1. Copious irrigation is crucial to minimize duration of contact with the chemical and to normalize the pH in the conjunctival sac as soon as possible. The speed and efficacy of irrigation is the most important prognostic factor following chemical injury.
  2. Topical anesthetic should be instilled prior to irrigation, as this dramatically improves comfort and facilitates cooperation. A lid speculum may be helpful. Tap water should be used if necessary to avoid any delay, but a sterile balanced buffered solution, such as normal saline or Ringer lactate, should be used to irrigate the eye for 15-30 minutes or until the measured pH is neutral.

Reference: Kanski clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 913

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient has axillary freckling, several firm subcutaneous masses on both arms and seven light-brown macules on his trunk which are greater than 1.5 cm as shown in the image. What will be the probable diagnosis of the child? -
questions.solution:
Neurofibromatosis is an autosomal dominant disorder, producing tumors along the course of nerves and occasionally resulting in marked soft tissue or bony deformity.

In > 90%, characteristic skin lesions are apparent at birth or develop during infancy. Lesions are medium-brown (café-au-lait), freckle-like macules, distributed most commonly over the trunk, pelvis, and flexor creases of elbows and knees.

During late childhood, flesh-colored cutaneous tumors of various sizes and shapes appear, ranging in number from several to thousands.

Diagnosis is clinical. There is no specific treatment, but tumors can be removed surgically.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., page no 2420

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of an ideal suicidal poison?
questions.solution:
The characters of an ideal suicidal poison should be:

  1. cheap
  2. easily available
  3. highly toxic
  4. tasteless or of pleasant taste
  5. capable of being easily taken in food or drink
  6. capable of producing painless death

Opium and barbiturates satisfy several of the above criteria.

Organophosphorus compounds and endrin are commonly used as suicidal poisons.

References: The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, Page 503

questions.text: Which of the following are major risk factors for recurrence of DCIS?
questions.solution:
Breast conservation is appropriate for most women but has a slightly higher risk of recurrence.

The major risk factors for recurrence are

  1. high nuclear grade and necrosis
  2. extent of disease
  3. positive surgical margins.

Postoperative radiation therapy and tamoxifen reduce the risk of recurrence.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1055

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-essential metal/ mineral?
questions.solution:
Following minerals have some functional role in the human body -

  • Calcium
  • Magnesium

choices.text: Femoral pulses are weak or absent
Femoral pulse occurs slightly before the radial pulse
Blood pressure in the legs is lower than that in the arms

questions.text: All the following are signs of coarctation of the aorta, except -
questions.solution:
The radial and femoral pulses should always be palpated simultaneously for the presence of a radial-femoral delay. Normally, the femoral pulse occurs slightly before the radial pulse. A radial-femoral delay occurs when blood flow to the descending aorta is dependent on collaterals, in which case the femoral pulse is felt after the radial pulse.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 2206

questions.text: As per IPHS 2022, one Polyclinic HWC-PHC established to cover population of?
questions.solution:
• As per IPHS 2022, one Polyclinic Health and Wellness Centre (HWC-PHC) is established to cover a population of 2.5 to 3.0 lakhs.
  • For Rural PHCs, the population norm is 30,000 in plain areas and 20,000 in hilly and tribal areas.
  • For Urban PHCs, the population norm is 50,000.
  • Polyclinic HWC-PHCs are designed to cater to a larger population to provide comprehensive healthcare services.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition - Page no: 483

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is referred for a new onset of bilateral epiphora. Examination shows eyelashes on both lower eyelids rubbing against the inferior cornea. The parents state that an older sibling has the similar symptoms, which resolved without treatment. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history and examination are most consistent with the diagnosis of epiblepharon.

Infants may be asymptomatic because their soft lashes do not irritate the cornea. As children age, the lashes become coarse, causing ocular irritation and epiphora.

The family history of a symptomatic sibling whose epiphora is resolved is consistent with the diagnosis of epiblepharon because the facial features in siblings are often similar.

As facial elongation occurs with age, epiblepharon can spontaneously resolve because excess skin is pulled inferiorly.

Entropion results from an inward rotation of the eyelid margin, which does not occur in epiblepharon. Entropion is unlikely to resolve spontaneously in a child.

Euryblepharon is a congenital widening of the palpebral fissure, usually involving increased vertical widening of the temporal portion.

Trichiasis describes misdirected eyelashes resulting from chronic inflammation of the eyelid margin.

Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page no 94

questions.text: A 29 years old woman complains of a lump on the left side of her neck since 4 months. Physical examination shows a non-tender nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid gland. Adjacent cervical lymph node is enlarged and non-tender. Laboratory studies show no thyroid auto-antibodies in her serum, and the T4 and TSH levels are normal. A thyroidectomy is performed. Image below shows the microscopic appearance of the nodule. What is the most common molecular alteration likely?
questions.solution:
As seen in image, the papillary architecture in this nodule, with cells that have clear nuclei, is a pattern typical for papillary carcinoma. These nuclear changes, even if the pattern is follicular, confirm the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma. Between 50% and 80% of conventional PTCs harbor gain-of-function mutations in the BRAF gene, most commonly a valine-to-glutamate change in codon 600 (BRAFV600E). BRAF encodes a serine/threonine kinase that lies downstream of receptor tyrosine kinases in growth factor signaling pathways.

Point mutations of TP53, beta-catenin (CTNNB1), and TERT (which encodes the catalytic component of the enzyme telomerase) - are essentially restricted to poorly differentiated and anaplastic carcinomas.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease 10th edition, Page no 1087-1088.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy developed small hypopigmented depressed scars after fingernail scratches; he has been treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for a rheumatic disease 6 weeks ago. Of the following, the NSAID that is most likely to cause such a unique skin reaction is -
questions.solution:
Naproxen is more likely than other NSAIDs to cause pseudoporphyria.

Pseudoporphyria is more likely to occur in fair-skinned individuals and in sun-exposed areas. If pseudoporphyria develops; the inciting NSAID should be discontinued because scars can persist for years or be permanent.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 3112

choices.text: Hyaline casts are composed of Tamm Horsfall protein
Waxy casts are common in mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis
Granular casts can be seen in renal allograft rejection
Fatty casts can be seen in nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding various casts seen in urine sediment examination?
questions.solution:
Waxy casts are uncommon in glomerular diseases, with the reported exception of post-infectious glomerulonephritis and renal amyloidosis.

Option A:Hyaline casts are the most frequently observed casts, consisting almost entirely of Tamm-Horsfall protein.

Option C:Granular casts appear with glomerular and tubular diseases but are also a feature of tubulointerstitial disease and renal allograft rejection. They may accompany pyelonephritis, viral infections, and chronic lead poisoning. Coarsely granular casts occur, with hematuria, in cases of renal papillary necrosis. Granular casts may also be seen following periods of extreme stress or strenuous exercise.

Option D:Fatty casts are commonly seen when heavy proteinuria is present and are a feature of nephrotic syndrome and nonproliferative glomerular diseases.

Reference: Henry's clinical diagnosis and management by laboratory methods, 24th edition, Page no 490-492

questions.text: What is the most common cause of severe hematemesis in children?
questions.solution:
Massive hematemesis in a child is almost always due to variceal bleeding.

Variceal bleeding is due to portal hypertension.

Reference: Nelson Pediatric symptom-based diagnosis, 20th edition, page no 208

choices.text: Assessment by a team specializing in autism spectrum disorders

questions.text: Mother of a 19-month-old girl who presents to you in OPD as she is concerned about her development. She was born at term but admitted in NICU for 14 days with meningitis. She is still only babbling and says no distinct words. She is able to walk, scribbles with crayons and feeds herself with a spoon. What is the most appropriate first action?
questions.solution:
Speech delay can be due to hearing impairment and this should be assessed first prior to referring her to a specialist. Neonatal meningitis is a known cause for sensorineural hearing loss.

Whilst autism is typified by expressive language difficulties this is only part of the problem. (Option b)

The problem may resolve spontaneously but further action is required if no clear words have emerged by 18 months. (Option c)

Getting to diagnose whether it is a conductive or sensory-neuronal cause is important before referring to an ENT surgeon. (Option d)

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 3075

choices.text: Aerobic metabolism shift to anerobic metabolism
Failure of hydrogen potassium pump occurs due to glucose depletion.
Potassium leaked outside of cell and causes adverse changes .

questions.text: All of the following pathophysiological changes would be seen at cell level in shock except:
questions.solution:
Due to oxygen deprivation cell start to use anerobic metabolism lactic acid is start to accumulate as by product of anerobic metabolism and systemic metabolic acidosis occur.

  • Ultimately due ti glucose deprivation anerobic metabolism also ceases and Na+/K+ pump fails.
  • Due to lysosomal release auto digestion started and cell lysis occurs that leads to release of K+ into blood stream.

REFERENCE: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery-28th Edition.
